150865968.review:
If this game had actually been finished it would very likely still be my personal favorite in the entire series, even after playing through DMC5. The combat is extremely smooth and responsive, and with Turbo Mode enabled it's fast paced to the point of feeling like an anime fight in almost every single encounter when you're styling hard on enemies.

The first half of the game is great. Nero is an easy to pick up character for newcomers to the series, while still offering an enjoyable skill ceiling for sweatlords, thanks to MAX-Act. Every single one of his special moves is intuitive to use and every single one of them serves a useful purpose, his glowy devil arm is fun as hell to use, he has ways of handling the enemies that you must to figure out on your own, but tend to be pretty straight forward most of the time, and he gets to fight one of the best bosses the series has. Really not much to complain about here (except for Chimera Assaults lol), the game shines the brightest during this half.

However, the game's second half is severely lacking due to the fact that it's just the same stages and bosses but played in backwards order (and the worst crime of all, you don't even get to fight the best boss in the game again, you only get to fight him in a single mission per difficulty, excluding the Bloody Palace mode...) ...and the playable character during this second half, Dante, is by far the jankiest character out of the 5 available in the Special Edition. He gains new mechanics/weapons at an incredibly overwhelming rate during your first playthrough, you most likely won't figure out their full potential as you'll have about half of Nero's missions to get used to him. But if you end up sticking with the game for a while longer, either to try and beat Bloody Palace or to beat the harder difficulties, DMC4 offers incredible depth and complexity in its combat system in a very much classic Capcom fashion, it honestly feels like one of their fighting games in this regard. DMC4 Dante, in particular, thanks to his ability to cancel most actions using his Block ability, his insane mobility with Trickster style, his ability to manipulate his own falling speed, and the versatility of his 3 melee & 3 gun arsenal, is the series' peak when it comes to pulling off completely insane wacky stylish shit if you're willing to grind a little more after you've beat the game for the first time.  Don't get me wrong though, even without diving into the (frankly excessive) tech skill rabbit hole, the game still offers a satisfying experience on a casual playthrough (I guess like a 7.5/10 overall? If I had to put it into numbers) but messing around with what the characters can do on subsequent playthroughs is where this game truly shines, in my opinion.

Oh yeah, and the music's fantastic. Story is whatever I guess.

149732585.review:
Es uno de los pocos juegos que he abandonado y de verdad, me da muchísima pena. Vengo de jugarme la colección de los tres primeros juegos que hay en Steam, y Devil May Cry 4 supone un cambio que te puede gustar, o no. Lo primero más notable es el cambio del protagonista que llevas durante la mitad del juego, Nero. He de decir que, aunque al principio se me hizo raro, Nero me ha encantado como protagonista, pues me recuerda en parte al Dante de Devil May Cry 3, el cual es mi versión de Dante favorita (sin contar el del 5, que aún no lo he jugado). 

Se introducen nuevas mecánicas como: la posibilidad de rodar para esquivar ataques y el poder rotar la cámara a placer en según qué situaciones, entre otras. Nombro estas dos porque son las que me causan controversia. Te dan la libertad  de rotar la cámara pero no siempre que quieras, la rotación completa a tu voluntad es solo en ciertas partes y en las partes que no, la puedes mover de forma muy limitada o ni siquiera eso. Esta característica, junto a la posibilidad de rodar, es un poco lo que me ha jodido la experiencia. A ver, rodar está de putísima madre, pero no cuando los ángulos de cámara son tan jodidamente raros, van cambiando a veces como les da la gana y la dirección a la que tienes que mover el joystick cambia, haciendo que a veces hagas una acción distinta a la de rodar por error. 

Todo lo anterior se podría considerar realmente como un problema de mi habilidad como jugador, soy consciente y por eso he aguantado tanto ese aspecto. El caso es que el diseño de las misiones tampoco es nada del otro mundo... Los jefes se basan en exactamente lo mismo y para nada son una experiencia estimulante. La mayoría de los niveles se basan en puzzles en los que te puedes caer y, si te caes, para volver a subir te obligarán a superar un combate; dichos combates no tienen un límite, siempre que te caigas estarás obligado a hacer uno. Este punto me lleva a la siguiente cosa que no me ha gustado, los enemigos. Me gusta el diseño de estos, pues es muy fiel a la estética que tenían los anteriores Devil May Cry, pero es que todos se basan en lo mismo: esquivar (de forma regulera por el problema que mencioné antes) y atacar. ¿No te apetece esquivar? Pues recibir ostias y atacar, al final acaba siendo lo mismo. No es que esté mal... Pero siento que en anteriores Devil May Cry, al carecer de esa mecánica, buscaban otras maneras de convertir en reto tanto a los jefes como a los enemigos normales. 

También le veo 0 sentido que no puedas bajar el nivel de dificultad. Si me lo estoy pasando en normal, debería ser capaz de poder acceder a la misma misión en fácil. Entiendo que la intención es que alguien no se pase el juego en fácil y luego juegue la última misión en difícil, pero podría haberse hecho que si juego en normal, desbloqueo también las misiones en fácil, pero no al revés. Intenté bajar la dificultad más que nada para ver si todas estas sensaciones negativas se mitigaban y al menos me lo pasaba para ver la historia, pero es que me niego a empezar de cero, especialmente porque otro detalle negativo a mi parecer es que han alargado muchísimo las misiones. 

La gracia de los DMC, en mi opinión, es que eran misiones cortas pero intensas; aquí pueden ser intensas, sí, pero es que de media cada misión dura 20 minutazos o más. Cierto es que no es tanto, pero viniendo de juegos anteriores en los que las misiones duraban 5-10 minutos de media... Pues bueno, es un aspecto que también me ha acabado aburriendo porque encima muchas veces el juego parece más una película que un juego, vamos, que hay demasiadas cinemáticas dentro de las misiones y encima algunas de ellas larguísimas. Hay muchos otros juegos que son así, de ahi el meme de "jugar una película", pero sin duda no es lo que esperaba de un hack and slash y menos de un DMC. 

En fin, entiendo por qué le gusta a la gente, no es un mal juego, de verdad; si lo pillas en una buena oferta, muy seguramente sea una buena compra, pero simplemente la cuarta entrega de la franquicia no es un juego para mi por los aspectos que ya he mencionado.

149645415.review:
Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition is a remastered version of the 2008 classic, breathing new life into the demon-hunting series that has captivated fans for over a decade. This Special Edition brings several enhancements to the table, making it a must-play for both newcomers and longtime fans of the franchise.

Gameplay (9/10):
The heart and soul of Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition lies in its fast-paced, combo-driven combat system. Players can choose from a diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique playstyle. Dante, Nero, and Vergil are back, and Lady and Trish join the roster, adding variety to the already impressive character selection. The combat mechanics are finely tuned, offering a deep and rewarding experience for those who take the time to master the game's intricacies. The style meter returns, encouraging players to perform stylish combos while dispatching waves of demonic foes. The gameplay is a spectacle of acrobatics and destruction, and the Special Edition offers even more options to experiment with, providing additional depth and replayability.

Graphics (8/10):
While Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition is a remaster of an older game, it still looks impressive. The character models, environments, and animations have been updated to match modern standards. The game runs smoothly, even during intense combat sequences, and the special effects and particle work enhance the overall experience. However, some of the textures and background elements show their age, reminding players that this is a remaster of an older title. Still, it's a testament to the original game's art design that it holds up so well.

Sound and Music (9/10):
The soundtrack of Devil May Cry 4 is legendary, and the Special Edition preserves the same iconic tunes that have become synonymous with the series. The voice acting is top-notch, with characters' personalities shining through, adding depth to the narrative. The sound effects are satisfying and make every hit, slash, and gunshot feel impactful.

Story and Narrative (7/10):
The Devil May Cry series has never been known for its deep, complex narratives, but rather for its stylish, over-the-top action. Devil May Cry 4 is no exception. The story revolves around a conflict between demons and the enigmatic Order of the Sword, with Dante and Nero caught in the middle. While the plot may be somewhat convoluted and melodramatic, it serves as a backdrop for the game's frenetic action and memorable characters.

Replayability (10/10):
Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition excels in replayability. With multiple characters to choose from, each with their own playstyle and abilities, players can approach the game in various ways. The Bloody Palace mode offers a challenging arena for testing your combat skills and competing for high scores. Moreover, the desire to achieve higher style rankings, unlock new moves, and discover hidden secrets will keep you coming back for more.

Overall (8.5/10):
Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition is a worthy remaster of a beloved classic that remains a shining example of stylish action gameplay. It doesn't just rest on the laurels of the original release; it adds even more variety and depth to the experience. While the story may not be the main draw, the addictive combat and high replayability make this Special Edition a must-play for fans of the series and anyone who enjoys thrilling, combo-driven action games. Whether you're a seasoned demon hunter or a newcomer to the franchise, Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition has something to offer, and it's sure to provide hours of demon-slaying entertainment.

148936976.review:
Devil May Cry 4 is a very interesting game since it came to known as an unfinished masterpiece and that may be confusing to process as you would find yourself frequently asking: "How could an unfinished game classified as a masterpiece?" and you'd be surprised to know that such a thing indeed exists. It was the summer of 2008 when I first got to try out this game and I was frustrated with the fact that it introduced a new lead called Nero. He struck me as a smug and unlikeable bastard at first but progressing further and witnessing his cries after Kyrie, I found him quite relatable real fast. Now I can't really decide between Dante, Vergil & Nero for they are all equally cool in their own ways. 

The first thing you'll notice about Nero is going to be his demon arm. It's never been explained why he has that arm in game or why it's so powerful but if you're looking for a lore explanation, I'd suggest reading its book. However, if you're wondering how it plays, I got you covered in the next few sentences. He doesn't have depth like Dante but he's very fun to play in his own way. The whole game is designed around him hence you may find him even better than Dante and you probably will. The Red Queen, his beloved sword, has a motorcycle-like grip and when twisted, you can perform powerful combos with it and strike the finishing blow by grabbing enemies with his arm. He has different finisher animations for each enemy and even bosses thus, you'll find yourself trying to execute each one. They deal huge damage and increase style meter real fast, too! It can also be used for some platforming sections.

After the 11th level, you'll start playing as Dante and his levels are going to show you the very reason why the game is crowned the title unfinished masterpiece. You'll be basically backtracking Nero's levels but at least they were generous enough to give you new weapons after defeating the same bosses again. So, what's different from DMC 3? You get to switch styles on the fly and that is freaking awesome! You don't have to grind experience points for them too! However, Dante's gameplay may be a bit difficult to get used to since almost all enemies are designed specifically for Nero. If you find yourself having a hard time, know that there are many options for you to try out since he's quite flexible compared to Nero. One thing I hated about Dante's levels was the only unique level of his featured the most annoying boss I've ever faced in any game: The Savior. The arena you fight it is quite confusing and it may take a while to get used to and what you exactly need to do isn't that obvious at first. Most people find Sanctus quite annoying, but I personally didn't have as many problems with him as I had with The Savior. 

So, I hear you ask what's so special about this Special Edition? Allow me to explain. You get to play as Vergil, Trish & Lady! Lady's gameplay is focused on guns, and she is basically the easiest character to play despite being quite distant from other characters. You just need to charge her shotgun to third level and start blasting! Your style meter will get to SSS real quick, and your enemies will melt in no time! If you're having difficulty on higher difficulties with other characters, Lady is the way to go. Vergil is also another GOD if you want sword gameplay and feel like a total badass while cutting and slicing your enemies. No further explanation necessary. Trish is... strange. While she's solely based on staggering and stunning enemies, her damage output is quite low hence you may find playing Bloody Palace as her quite difficult. Normal levels are not that bad, and I'd go as far to say playing as her is actually a lot of fun! Unfortunately, all new playable characters only have 2 cutscenes at the beginning and at the end of the game. Lady & Trish's storyline may fit into the canon, but I don't know much about Vergil's. 

The overall level design of the game is bigger compared to previous entries, but you'll get used to it. I don't know if I should talk about the story at all because anything I say could be a spoiler so, I think it's best to keep my mouth shut on this matter. Let's talk about DLCs instead. I personally wouldn't recommend buying anything other than extra costumes for they are all unlockable in game by normal means. It's also best to keep in mind that super characters give huge score penalty this time around thus, it's impossible to get an S rank from levels using them and cheesing your way through levels. They're quite fun to use, though. Especially Super Vergil. Bloody Palace becomes a breeze if you equip them which you will most likely need after a few failed attempts. Good luck with Trish, though. She lacks a super costume and taking her low damage output into account, you're in for a treat! 

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
An unfinished masterpiece with a new lead and a refined gameplay with several characters to play as such as Lady, Trish & Vergil. I personally like its storyline a lot and it's also the hardest Devil May Cry game to 100% without a doubt so, good luck!

DMC4 is a pretty good game, bringing back the stylish gameplay that was perfected in DMC3, and implementing it just as well. You'll have lots of fun mixing attacks together for flashy and powerful combos, jumping around enemies as you taunt and play around with them.

Although the game is a lot of fun, it does have its flaws. The enemies and bosses are clearly designed around Nero's gameplay, meaning that Dante has a much harder time dealing with them. It's not that noticiable on Devil Hunter difficulty and below, but once you try the higher difficulties it does become very apparent.

Overall, this game is the good DMC experience that any fan of the franchise craves for. It's also full of replayability, which is always a very good thing.

147829747.review:
Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition trae consigo la acción intensa y estilizada por la que la serie es conocida, junto con algunas mejoras y contenido adicional. Aunque el juego ofrece una experiencia sólida y emocionante, tiene algunos problemas que afectan su calificación.

Gráficos y Diseño Visual (8/10):
Los gráficos han sido mejorados desde la versión original, con personajes y entornos detallados que lucen impresionantes. Los efectos visuales durante los combates son dinámicos y emocionantes. Sin embargo, algunas texturas y modelos de personajes pueden parecer un poco desactualizados en comparación con los títulos más recientes.

Jugabilidad (9/10):
La jugabilidad es el punto fuerte de Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition. Los controles son precisos y responsivos, lo que permite a los jugadores realizar combos fluidos y elaborados. La variedad de personajes jugables y sus estilos de lucha únicos añaden profundidad y replayability al juego. Sin embargo, la curva de aprendizaje puede ser empinada para los nuevos jugadores debido a la complejidad de los movimientos avanzados.

Contenido y Variedad (8/10):
La Special Edition trae consigo tres nuevos personajes jugables, cada uno con su propio estilo de lucha. Esto agrega variedad y horas adicionales de juego para aquellos que ya están familiarizados con la historia principal. Sin embargo, algunas misiones pueden sentirse repetitivas, y la trama puede resultar confusa para los recién llegados a la serie.

Diversión y Duración (7/10):
La diversión en Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition radica en la satisfacción de dominar los complicados movimientos y derrotar a enemigos desafiantes. Sin embargo, la repetición de ciertas secciones y la falta de innovaciones significativas en comparación con las entregas anteriores pueden hacer que la experiencia se vuelva monótona para algunos jugadores. La duración del juego es decente, pero algunos podrían sentir que la trama se estira innecesariamente en ciertos puntos.

Conclusión:
Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition es una sólida adición a la serie, ofreciendo acción intensa y compleja que hará las delicias de los fans de los juegos de hack and slash. Aunque tiene ciertos problemas de repetición y una curva de aprendizaje empinada para los nuevos jugadores, sigue siendo un título emocionante para aquellos que buscan una experiencia de combate desafiante y gratificante.

Calificación: 7.7/10

147663095.review: I loved this game when I first played at 2008 but now it doesn’t feel good. Obviously, graphics were great for 15 years ago but now it is not great, though it was playable for me. Music is fantastic, especially the one at the beginning of the game. Writing style was enjoyable with the comedic touch and being weird as a fun way. Even though story was decent, there were lots of holes in it. Most of the time, I did not get why I am going to a certain place for looking Dante or doing something. Still these weren’t big problems for me. The most important part was the gameplay for me: Sadly, this was the problem for me. Although, there were a lot of combos with different characters, only Nero/Dante part was canonical which means you have to play the same game without story to experience the other characters which makes it a bit repetitive and senseless. Plus, the achievements require you to complete the same game over and over for at least 7 times. Even without the other characters, game uses the same places and the same bosses for multiple times (there was a problem with the budget I think). Last two chapters were horrendous for me, with the dice parts for no reason and annoying boss. I had hard time dodging the enemy skills, since it was hard for me to see with the old graphics. However, most important problem was the tutorial and the keys. The game gives the tutorial with the PlayStation keys and when you check the skills, you can only see those keys which makes learning a trial and error with weird key mapping or research from the web. Lastly, I can say that controls were a bit unresponsive and the camera angles were really bad also. Therefore, I cannot recommend this game to anyone, especially with this expensive price for 15 years old game.

146563520.review:
DMC4 is my favourite out of the 5. It is also the first DMC game I've ever played. I remember watching the trailer when it was first announced for PS3 and I was so enamoured watching the reviews (I never had PS3).
When I realised it came out for PC, I had to have it and honestly, I wasn't disappointed. It delivered on everything I wanted - a sappy love story, great action (made only better with the Nero's demon arm), okayish story... and all that a whole decade later — as I originally played it back in 2018.
With the Special Edition, I've just finished it for what I believe 3rd time — it is still one of the best action games I've ever played.
I wholeheartedly recommend DMC4 if you are looking for some fun action. Game has higher difficulties (unlocked after finishing the game on easy or normal) which are quite the challenge!

146523363.review:
This was the only DMC game I hadn't played, growing up playing 1-3 and later visiting 5. I honestly think it's a good game, though it also has very noticeable flaws. Granted, depending on who you are you can overlook them to varying degrees. I beat the main campaign on my initial run-through in around 17 hours give or take with some downtime AFK - leaving room for a short story but a lot of replayability as with other DMC games.


[h1][u]I'll put a TL;DR at the bottom.[/u][/h1]


[b][u]For the good points: [/u][/b]
- The game has a fun combat system, Nero is a very good character introduced into DMC4 with a fun move set and his buster is cool. Dante's weapons are cool as well, I prefer Gilgamesh compared to Balrog in 5 for example, and Lucifers concept is sick.
- The music is good; Berial's theme is nice in my opinion, as well as The Time Has Come are two songs that stand out to me. Overall good soundtrack especially if you enjoy more religious, church-y music with a twist.
- Story is nice. Dante takes a backseat, allowing Nero to shine - and the voice acting Nero provides is PHENOMENAL as well as the emotion portrayed by him for Kyrie. Plot wise, I really enjoy what this game brought to the series - even though it may have plot holes. Their relationship is very cute and I enjoyed it a lot.
- 5 playable characters is a nice touch, Vergil is a popular character that returns in this game as well as Lady and Trish making their debut as playable characters which we don't get anywhere else. In the main campaign it's split between Nero and Dante, with Nero's missions being more engaging, so if you're a fan of Nero then the gameplay will be good for you.
- The visuals of the game are very nice especially for the original release being in 2008 prior to the Special Edition, and I really love the aesthetics each area provides. Very pretty for its age, and I adore Nero's character design as this is my favorite design of his between 4 and 5.


[b][u]For the bad points:[/u][/b]
- The game is very repetitive, half the campaign is going through the same levels and bosses you've already done, fighting them a total of 3 times, and backtracking into the same level design per Nero and Dante. This is where it varies - if you're like me, I don't particularly mind backtracking, so this doesn't turn me off much. If I love the aesthetic of the level, I don't really mind. This will be different for everyone.
- A lot of enemies are designed around Nero and Dante's kit was not fully thought out, so some enemies are tougher on characters that aren't Nero and may be frustrating (Example: Cutlass/Sharks) I personally think this game has a lot of enemies that are annoying or frustrate me, but I can also see the appeal of them being fun for others. Dante's combat in this game with these enemies isn't always favorable.
- Compared to Vanilla, Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition has some input lag and performance issues that make it sometimes difficult to load up. I didn't have this problem, in regards to crashing, and I didn't notice the input lag my first run through, but I know it's an issue for some players and has been mentioned a lot by the community. For a casual run I think this version is fine.


Overall, while a flawed game, it's a fun one and definitely a game I recommend any modern-day DMC fans or Nero fans to play, especially if you enjoy more heartfelt stories. The combat overall feels pretty smooth, especially as Nero - I would include Dante with practice on him as he isn't easy - and fun to play with. If you like more unique enemies then the design in this game will be more for you as you can't just wildly swing at them either. Overall it's pleasing to the eye, but also repetitive if that isn't your thing.


[h1][b]TL;DR:[/b][/h1]


[b]Graphics[/b] - 4/5 [i]Nice for its time. Very pretty.[/i]
[b]Gameplay[/b] - 3/5 [i]Very good combat but repetitive level design.[/i]
[b]Audio[/b] - 4/5 [i]dmc soundtracks are good and dmc4 delivers, though I think it's outclassed by 3 and 5. Nero's voice actor did an amazing job in this game as well.[/i]
[b]Difficulty[/b] - Medium, [i]some enemies require more brainpower but the game isn't hard on Human/Devil Hunter.[/i]
[b]Grind[/b] - No grind [i]unless you want to do the rest of the difficulties or Bloody Palace. [/i][b][i]First runthrough isn't a grind at all.[/i][/b]
[b]Story[/b] - Good. [i]Nice emotional story but short. Establishes a relationship between Nero and Kyrie.[/i]
[b]Price[/b] - if it's on sale, it's worth picking up. [i]I got it on sale for $7 CAD and I don't regret it at all.[/i]
[b]Bugs[/b] - Moderate, some may encounter ones other do not. [i]My experience was bug-free, but your mileage may vary.[/i]
[b]OVERALL[/b] - 7/10, worth on sale, good but flawed game. Enjoyable and worthwhile experience if you like combat and don't mind repetition.

146195613.review:
DMC4 used to be the DMC game I was utterly split on whether I like it or not. I think that after replaying it I have finally decided that I like it, but that it's also not perfect. 

For starters I really love the characters, especially how Nero is portrayed and I don't really mind Dante taking a backseat for most of the game, I really like how the combat and combos layed the foundation of what would be DMC5 later down the line and as always, the music rocks. 

However as much praise as I can give the game for these facts alone, everyone at this point knows that DMC4 was a rushed game. As hard as I try to like the story and locations of the game, it just doesn't end up feeling satisfying, unlike DMC1 or DMC3 for example which I personally think did their job way better years prior. And let's not mention the dice minigame missions. It just also doesn't feel good refighting the same bosses as an excuse for the game being cut in half or whatever.

That aside, I still think DMC4 is a must play and is definitely not a low point in the series, especially knowing how far down that goes when you take into account that DMC2 exists. There is simply too much content here and tons of things to learn.

Play this game, you won't regret it, but keep an open mind if you end up disliking the weaker parts of it.

Title: A Devilishly Divine Spectacle! - My Review of "Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition"

"Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition" is a mesmerizing roller-coaster ride through the realms of the supernatural, redefining the benchmark for stylish action games. Capcom has outdone themselves with this special edition, elevating an already acclaimed title to new heights. As I plunge deeper into this demonic adventure, I can't help but be awestruck by the sheer brilliance of this game.

From the very beginning, "Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition" showers players with breathtaking visuals that push the boundaries of what's possible in gaming. The updated graphics are nothing short of a masterpiece. The character designs, environments, and particle effects are so detailed and polished that you'll frequently find yourself pausing just to admire the intricacies of Dante's iconic coat or the grotesque beauty of the demonic foes he faces.

The heart and soul of "Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition" lie in its game-play, and this edition takes it to a whole new level. With the inclusion of fan-favorite characters like Vergil, Lady, and Trish, each with their unique play-styles, the game offers unparalleled depth and variety. Nero's Devil Bringer and Dante's style-switching mechanics have never been more fluid and intuitive, making every battle feel like an electrifying dance of death. The combat system is so intricately balanced that newcomers and veterans alike will find joy in mastering its nuances.

While Devil May Cry games aren't necessarily known for their intricate storytelling, "Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition" makes strides in this department. The narrative unfolds with unexpected twists and reveals that keep you engaged from start to finish. The enigmatic world of demons and supernatural forces is enriched by the memorable characters, even if the storytelling occasionally dips into campy territory. The addition of Vergil's perspective on events adds depth to the narrative, making it an even more engaging experience.

The sound design in "Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition" is nothing short of stellar. The pulse-pounding soundtrack complements the frenetic action sequences perfectly, creating an atmosphere of tension and excitement. The voice acting, especially from the returning cast, is top-notch and oozes charisma. Dante's witty one-liners and Vergil's stoic demeanor are brought to life with superb performances.

"Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition" is a gift that keeps on giving. With multiple playable characters, a variety of difficulty modes, and the Bloody Palace mode, there's no shortage of reasons to come back for more demon-slaying action. Each character offers a distinct experience, and the thrill of mastering their moves and tackling higher difficulties is immensely satisfying. The game is a treasure trove of hidden secrets and challenges waiting to be uncovered.

In conclusion, "Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition" is a triumphant return to the demon-hunting series, refining and expanding upon what made the original so great. It's a masterpiece of stylish action, boasting stunning visuals, thrilling game-play, and a devilishly entertaining story. Whether you're a seasoned Devil May Cry veteran or a newcomer, this game is a must-play, offering hours upon hours of spectacular entertainment. Capcom has once again proven that when it comes to stylish action games, they are the true masters of the genre.

145090566.review:
Maybe I was burnt out, as it was my fourth Devil May Cry game in a row at that point, but wow does DMC 4 not hit the same as the previous ones. Barring the second game, of course, DMC 2 doesn't exist.

At first, I didn't like the main character change. Nero seemed much simpler than Dante in every way... and he was. But by the time I made it to the second half of the game, I realized the entire game was designed around Nero. Playing as Dante wasn't the same, he felt tacked on. Especially when the second half is pretty much a rethread of the first.

Gameplay is still phenomenal, don't get me wrong, but there's something missing in this one. I'm not sure what it is. Bosses are okay, not too memorable. There are a couple that outshone the rest, though. But the moment to moment gameplay kinda lost me nearing 70/75% of the game. Puzzles were inoffensive, not bad but not really good either.

The reused locations and bosses from the first half made this even worse. I don't like using the word 'lazy' when talking about game development but it really feels like it. It was probably a time constraint issue. It REALLY affects the overall quality. I almost dropped the game because of it. 

The plot might be the weakest across all games imo. I never cared about whatever the main villain was babbling about, and I felt tempted to skip some cutscenes because of sheer disinterest. But honestly... Who cares lmao it's Devil May Cry.

Aesthetically it's pretty good. It looks clean and aged pretty well. No complaints here.

I'm still recommending it, there's a lot of fun to be had. I just had to push a bit through the second half.

6.5/10

144948268.review:
Unfinished game.
Ok so first of all:
-Steam Overlay doesn't work. But it actually does. It's just invisible and you can't interact with it. So if you're hearing weird music and sounds it's because the steam overlay opens automatically when you open the game and it's playing a trailer from the DMC 4 store page, invisibly. I'm not joking.
- Alt+Tab makes the game go on windowed mode. Like seriously?
-Performance Issues for no reason. I have a beefy PC and this game came out on 2008. It runs even worse on windowed mode. Didn't have any problems on DMC 1-3 and 5 when it comes to performance.
-When you go to "PC Settings" to change the graphical settings, the game just crashes. And you have to troubleshoot it to get it to work. Bruh?
-Hotkeys don't work. So you can't change the volume of the game while playing it nor alt+f4. If you wanna change the volume you gotta alt+tab... which causes problems as stated above.

The actual game:

Bad and annoying enemy design (Faults, Faust, Frosts, Blitzes, Chimeras, Assaults...), obnoxious gimmicks and pace-breaking puzzles, the platform is based on timing (grappling hooks) instead of actual platforming, lame boss design (one of the bosses is a window, another one is a giant frog), lack of story, repetitive and bland level design, mind blowing technical issues (steam, pc), grindy achievements (irrelevant for most people, not me), poor character balance (the character you can most easily S rank on is also the most straight-forward and boring... and it's supposed to be *STYLISH* ranks btw). Pardon me if I'm forgetting something.

It's clearly unfinished. The game has 20 missions. If you play up to mission 11 you've seen all of the areas, the rest of the missions are backtracking with a few additional assets. Even the same boring bosses are the same. If you want all the achievements you'll be doing about 8 playthroughs. Now, I and many people already got bored with the 2nd half of the game on the 1st playthrough, so just imagine my despair upon this realization.

The game was clearly designed with Nero in mind. He has gap closers (both player displacement and enemy displacement), easy aerial combos, a ranged weapon that supports melee combat (just charge it and use it once in the middle of a combo), and the Devil Bringer (only grabbing attack in the game), which can be used on bosses, has unique interactions with each enemy and it's sick. He can do everything.

Then you have Dante which clearly was supposed to have his own campaign, but instead he's put against the same enemies and areas as Nero, which just feels uncomfortable with Dante's moveset. The 1% of the playerbase are gonna argue that it has an extremely intricate combat system, etc etc... But how many people are gonna realistically master this game? First you need to *like* the game and it's core mechanics, then you master it.

Vergil is cool tho. However missions like mission 6 are a disaster as Him.

After getting all of the achievements on DMC 4, I felt pain and dread. Overall, not worth it.

Resumen: Un insulto completo al nombre Devil May Cry. 

Nunca en mi vida había presenciado una oda tan descarada a la pereza y la mediocridad. Todo el juego está diseñado para estirar artificialmente su duración de forma ridículamente frustrante. Y es una pena porque inicialmente estaba muy bueno, los combos de Nero me parecían una evolución muy bien lograda del juego y el devil bringer me pareció una adición excelente, aunque al final también lo jodieron, más de eso después. Hay muchas cosas buenas obviamente, además de la jugabilidad de Nero me encanto la forma en la que se explora a los personajes, me recordó mucho a dmc3 por eso, y tambien me gusto que lo hicieran una historia romántica, por que la verdad me encanta el romance, y de eso va esto. El protagonista salvando a la chica que ama, lo de salvar al mundo es solo parte del proceso. Pero hasta ahí llega lo bueno.

El primer error que note es que el devil bringer es demasiado corto y lento, solo te sirve con los enemigos más inútiles con los que realmente no importa si lo usas o no, pero cuando realmente lo necesitas, como en las batallas de jefe contra el cuarto de contención o Sanctus, resulta casi inutil, Y si logras agarrar a Sanctus, ¡Ni siquiera te deja en una ubicación óptima para atacar! También Nero es lentísimo para recuperarse de las caídas y, el mayor insulto, ya no puedes recuperarte desplazándote en alguna dirección, el bicho te pega, te hace volar y te recuperas en donde caíste, pero como media hora después. Valla retroceso más garrafal en ese aspecto

Lo segundo que noté es la nerfeada tan brutal que le metieron a Dante, es que es insultante. No solo la pelea contra Dante es la más difícil del juego, siendo él más rápido y fuerte que tu y adaptándose a tus movimientos lo que la hace una pelea no difícil sino injusta, sino que cuando lo manejas disparas confeti y golpeas con un pitillo plástico. Y no es que los enemigos sean más fuertes ni nada de eso, porque comparándolo con Vergil, a quien ya había comparado en dmc3, se nota la diferencia de dps tan abismalmente exagerada. El daño que hace es ridículamente bajo a tal punto que el modo DMD se me hacía eterno. Y para añadir más insulto los combos que hacen un daño más o menos decente, tienen una posibilidad ridícula de fallar, haciéndolos inútiles, no los puedes cancelar, dejándote vulnerable al daño, pero los enemigos si que te lo pueden cancelar, lo que es probable ya que estas vulnerable, por lo que son básicamente un bonito adorno con una utilidad práctica casi nula. Es de lejos el peor personaje del juego.

Pero lo peor, la razón por la que deje de jugar el juego en el modo DMD, es el cambio del sistema guardado que hicieron. Un cambio que el único objetivo es forzarte a grindear. En los primero 3 dmc en las dificultades más altas siempre guardaba antes de los jefes porque sabía que iba necesitar objetos y no quería desperdiciarlos. Asi tambien iba a cumulando las gemas rojas del nivel, por lo que cada vez que llegaba al jefe iba un poquito mejor preparado. Sin importar cuantas veces muriera no sentía que estaba perdiendo el tiempo, ya que cada muerte me dejaba un poquito mejor preparado y de paso podía gestionar cuantos y que objetos estaba dispuesto a invertir en cada pelea. Aqui no, aqui si te mueres, te jodes, perdiste todos tus objetos usados. Y para empeorarlo todo, gracias a la porqueria que es el menú, considérate afortunado si por accidente no selecciona la opción errada, lo que me paso muchisimas veces, aumentando aún más el desperdicio de recursos y la frustración.

Y ese es el último punto, lo jodidamente frustrante que es este jugeo. No sólo estás luchando con la maldita cámara que a este punto ya se que es una característica clásica del juego, pero joder, ya arreglenla. Sino que también está el desperdicio de objetos, que si crees que no fue deliberada, me sorprenderé si te graduaste de primaria. Y también tenemos enemigos que no te dejan atacar por minutos enteros. Esto se hace ridículamente eterno en DMD donde el tiempo que requiere matar enemigos se alarga. Las Chimeras son un ejemplo de esto. Utilizan su ataque de mover las lianas al azar tan a menudo que prácticamente tienes que matarlas con armas de fuego y con Dante eso se echara una eternidad, aun con Pandora, sin mencionar que arruina por completo el dinamismo y variedad del juego haciéndolo repetitivo y aburrido. En la batalla del cuarto de contención pasa lo mismo, hay tantos enemigos que simplemente no hay tiempo de atacar haciendo la batalla larga y tediosa y no hablo de la pelea con Sanctus porque ahí si me da una embolia. 

Y para finalizar, abuso más descarado: los logros. Mientras que en los primeros dmc me saque todos los logros pasandomelos en cada dificultad y el palacio sangriento y ya, aquí se esforzaron por hacer los logros lo más tediosos y frustrantes que pudieran, un gran logro en un juego de devil may cry debo decir. Debes matar a los jefes con estilo SSS, pero no hay forma de enfrentarlos solo a ellos, por lo que diviértete repitiendo todo el nivel si por casualidad los matas con SS, como me paso tres veces, y lo de pasarte todos los niveles en rango S en DMD, la gracia de ese reto en el DMC3 era que lo podías hacer en facil, asi que si fallabas solo habrías desperdiciado algunos minutos, y eran minutos de juego muy divertidos, rápidos y frenéticos, pero con lo frustrante, tedioso y repetitivo que se hace el modo DMD por sí mismo, bueno, desde un principio decidí ni molestarme en sacarlos. Claro que el juego resultó ser aún peor de lo que esperaba, por lo que al final ni me molesté en sacar logros que ya había planeado obtener, como el de completar el juego en todos los niveles de dificultad. Ah, por cierto, en que porqueria de juego cuando te lo pasas el modo normal no sacas el del modo fácil de una vez? De verdad, que vagancia de los programadores, es que ni se esforzaron por disimularlo.

Y aqui termina mi biblia de reseña para este juego. Una verdadera decepción para mi que era un gran fan de esta saga. Realmente espero que dmc5 me recupere. Si llegaste hasta aquí, realmente me sorprende que alguien se moleste en leer todo lo que escribí. De verdad muchas gracias por tomarte el tiempo para hacerlo.

143120120.review:
This is probably my favourite game of the series. I love the music, Nero, Kyrie and Dante in my opinion plays better in this one than in any of the previous ones, only DMC3 may come a little bit above this(in terms of Dante's gameplay). Some boss fights are kinda of anoying and the variety of these is kinda mid, to be frank. But the visuals, the direction, the story, the character and enemy design, the enviromental design and the music are without shadow of a doubt my favourites of the whole series, only DMC5 comes close to rivaling that statement, specially in the music department, where I think DMC5 takes the cake by a long shot. 
So yeah I really like this game even though I recognize that in some aspects, it can feel flat or uninteresting. But because of some nostalgia and love for this type of game and general aesthetic I still feel very passionate about this.
And hope you will find something of a similar feeling after playing it. Just remember to have fun with it.

while i am unable to break the laws of reality that bind us to this mortal tether unlike those who have mastered the few glitches of dmc4 combat, it is nevertheless a paragon of excellent game design. please see my resume of reasons why i am justified in recommending this game below. also, you can play as lady, trish and vergil in addition to the usual roster. play the series and discover why that is a triumph of choice

because of this game series i have:
- written a several-thousand word synopsis for the entire series several times for several people upon the slightest prompting
- listened to the soundtrack to such an extent my 2019 spotify in-review had one single song not on the DMC OST (omegaman - the police)
- written several fanfiction stories, some erotic and some not involving several characters for the series
- engaged in hosted DMC tournaments where the top dogs are the most stylish 
- poured at least three thousand hours into the series since i first saw that DMC1 PS2 case at gamestop all those years ago
- gained such a strong love of the early-00s culture the series represents that i automatically like any other game that exudes that culture
- expressed my sheer adoration for this series to such an extent that for my birthday i was given a surprise cameo gift from vergil's VA (lotus accord 4 lyfe)
- created an archive of any and all DMC images i come across, as well as stored a personal backup of several DMC fansites just in case
- discovered an appreciation for blondes through delving into the hidden depths of trish's character. to have someone who is on the surface a flirty succubus but holds a duality of naivete, intellect and earnestness best represented by her characterization from dmc1-> the anime -> 5 is a superb example of the trope. also dmc4 trish x dmc5 lady 4 lyfe
- enjoyed playing devil may cry

its good

140689371.review:
The time has come, and so have I. 

Before I start this I just want to say two things: the first being that I am dyslexic and not very good with grammar so I apologize if some of this review doesn’t really make sense, with other parts being much more well written. 
Second: I played this on steam deck; It works perfectly for me and I’ve had no issues like crashing, glitches, etc. funnily enough despite being ‘unsupported’ I had everything running at the highest settings with 60hz and I never had any dips. 
But, with that out of the way this is my review of Devil May Cry 4: special edition. This is most definitely one of my personal favorites in the series with (unsurprisingly) extremely fun gameplay mixed with loveable cornball writing and cheesy one liners. Having that in one package of pure stylistic badassery, and where’s better to start a review of any DMC other than the Smokin’ Sexy stylish combat, I’ll start off with Nero 
The devil bringer arm is badass as all hell, probably one of my favorite tools in the game, using it to snatch an enemy to you do a delay hit combo B whilst revving the Red Queen hit after hit EX-streaking them, snatching them again and using the bringer arm to slam them into the the ground violently is so badass and satisfying, really makes you *feel* like a hot-headed teenager with the exaggerated swagger of Sparda. Red Queen & blue rose are both also great tools, even if a little limiting at times and not really being able to stagger enemies with blue rose, (which is a change they made in DMCV—and a great one at that, but that’s a review for another day.) it’s still mountains of fun.
While Nero isn’t as technically robust as Dante i think he still has a great level of control and variety—especially when you start using charge shots, jump cancels, and start nailing those perfect EX-act’s with the Red Queen, the timing is brutal & unforgiving but puts a heavy skill ceiling on him in that regard. The timing and split second decisions of playing any DMC game just feels like a big puzzle with multiple options on how to style the everliving f*ck out of your opponents and what certain weaknesses to exploit and if you want to do that and have your style meter go down. 

Now, As much as I love playing as Dante it just didn’t entirely work for me at times personally due the reused levels, it makes your time with him a lot less special. I know the devs didn’t really have time but hey, what can you do (+it doesn’t really matter anymore since DMCV exists) I absolutely love Dante in this game, cocky as always with an unprecedented level of skill in kicking demon ass, not only does this game have the classic “What the hell is this?!” Line, but introduced switching styles on the fly with the D-pad, which opened his gameplay massively in being able to string together fun yet complex combos. I can’t really give any examples of combos that I enjoy doing like I was able to do with Nero due to dante being much more…well, Dante. I will try my best though: playing as Dante is like making a playground or building a set you made with a massive bucket of loose Lego’s, there’s no other feeling that can compare to using the rebellion to combo someone, upper slicing them hit em twice drop it jump cancel rapid fire guns to rainstorm finishing it off with a full Rebellion combo B and taunting. Dante isn’t fun because he’s Dante, Dante is fun because he is a playground of tools to do whatever you want and s|-|itpost on demons because you can. 

Moving to the story I don’t really have much to say, I’m really glad Nero was made and introduced for this game, ever since I played it as a kid I loved him and how he acted. He’s righteous, funny, and filled with a level of loyalty to kyrie I don’t think that can be replicated in another game for me….or maybe my rose tinted glasses are still on and I refuse to take them off. Dante & Nero interacting is always a real treat, they managed to write them both decently well and map a blueprint that was eventually used for the writing in DMCV to a great effect imo. Dante at the beginning felt like this final boss with unpredictability Nero would never be able to catch up with, having the loveable goofy pizza munching demon Hunter posed as a cold blooded killer at the beginning was both shocking and intriguing, I like how the story and the characterization was handled here.

After hours of gameplay and two play throughs, I think it’s a good game despite “not being finished”, I don’t really have much else to say about the game aside from minor nitpicks and pacing issues I had (and the mentioned reused Dante levels). I can’t really score this game at all due to those rose tinted glasses. but, can say: if you can get it, and you like DMC. you should, it’s good. 



Also: FUCK DICE GAME.

140358030.review:
Muy recomendable para fans de los combates cuerpo a cuerpo rápidos y ágiles con recreación especial en jefes de zona. Una jugabilidad basada en un sistema de lucha muy pulido y profundo en tipos de armas y multitud de combos, con exploración y puzles demasiado poco frecuentes. La narrativa es mucho más elaborada y compleja que en las tres entregas previas, aunque sigue sin ser un punto fuerte. Un diseño artístico acorde a la saga, pero más refinado y detallado, el cual destaca por un potente acabado técnico. Destacan la solidez de los escenarios, los modelados de los personajes y la fluidez de las animaciones, siendo visualmente muy llamativo.

Es un juego más largo y variado que los anteriores, aunque algo menos exigente en la dificultad de combates y plataformeo, destacando los diseños de escenarios diferentes donde la jugabilidad va cambiando ligeramente de enfoque. La 2ª mitad se hace algo pesada al repetir algunos niveles y enemigos con Dante, aún con ciertas variaciones, elevando la duración de forma un poco tosca e innecesaria, algo que ya ocurría con Devil May Cry 3. Una entrega muy continuista que perfecciona la acción y el guión, pero que ya mostraba síntomas de repetición y una necesidad de cambios para mantener fresca y relevante la saga.

8’2

Análisis completo: https://yexreviews.wordpress.com/2023/06/19/devil-may-cry-4-2008-special-edition-2015/

140082199.review:
Ah, Devil May Cry 4, a thrilling demon-slaying adventure that brings both joy and frustration to players. As the Goddess of Water and a lover of action-packed games, allow me to share a review that highlights the positive aspects of the game while acknowledging its flaws.

Devil May Cry 4 is an exhilarating addition to the iconic Devil May Cry series, offering fans and newcomers alike a chance to immerse themselves in the stylish and fast-paced combat that the franchise is known for. The game's visuals are simply breathtaking, with detailed environments and character designs that truly draw players into its dark and haunting world.

The combat mechanics are where Devil May Cry 4 truly shines. As Dante and Nero, players have access to an array of flashy and impressive moves, unleashing devastating combos on hordes of demonic foes. The combat system rewards skill and precision, making every battle feel like a dance of blades and bullets.

Moreover, the inclusion of Nero, with his unique Devil Bringer arm, adds a refreshing twist to the gameplay, allowing for a mix of close-quarters combat and long-range attacks. This dynamic duo of playable characters ensures that the game never feels repetitive, keeping players on their toes throughout the adventure.

Additionally, the level design is imaginative and varied, showcasing stunning set pieces and challenging platforming sections that demand both wits and reflexes. The seamless transition between battles and exploration keeps the pace exhilarating, ensuring there's rarely a dull moment.

However, even in this demon-slaying masterpiece, there are a few flaws that must be acknowledged. One of the game's most significant drawbacks is the backtracking. Players are required to replay several levels with the other character, which can feel repetitive and hinder the game's pacing.

Furthermore, the storyline, while intriguing, can be convoluted at times, making it challenging to fully grasp the motivations of certain characters and the overall plot direction.

Lastly, some may find the difficulty spikes a bit too steep, leading to moments of frustration, especially during boss battles, where mastering the intricacies of the combat system becomes crucial.

Despite these flaws, Devil May Cry 4 remains an exhilarating and visually stunning action game that's sure to captivate fans of the genre. With its stylish combat, imaginative world, and memorable characters, it delivers an experience that's well worth diving into. So, grab your sword and get ready to slice through the demon hordes in this epic demon-hunting adventure!

139926970.review:
If this will be your first/only experience with Devil May Cry 4 then you should definitely get this version. The Special Edition is simply superior to the original as it runs better (assuming you have a strong PC) and it has more options to play around with.

HOWEVER! If you already have/have played the original version of DMC4 then your mileage with this version varies depending on what you enjoy most about the series.

Do you play these games for the gameplay? Are you the kind of person that enjoys playing levels over and over again to try and rack up stylish points, get better scores, and/or wanna see how far you can push the limits of a character's arsenal? If so then you should get this version of the game. The characters, gameplay-wise, have a lot of thought and depth put into their combat. And with the fact that each character/set of characters have their own score sheet, the game implores you to truly test and master each character.

OR

Do you play this series for the story? Are you interested in the DMC lore? Wanna learn more about the tragic stories of characters you love? Or just to laugh at the adventures of wacky woohoo pizza man and his crew of not-as-funny but just as sexy demon killers? If so then you should NOT get this version of the game. There are less than 10 minutes of new cutscenes (unless you count the 30-second scenes of Nero silently doing something simple like walking across a bridge except his model is switched with someone else) and there is but an unsatisfying crumb of new lore that explains nothing at all.

9.5/10

ภาค 1-2 คุณภาพเกมโดยรวมเปรียบเหมือนความละเอียด 480p
ภาค 3 ได้มีการนำข้อดีและข้อเสียมาประยุกต์ใช้กับภาค 3 Upgrade ภาพและ gameplay ขึ้นมาเป็นระดับ 720p
ภาค 4 ก็ต้องเรียกว่าเป็น 1080p60 เลย 

อย่างแรกภาพสวยขึ้นมามากกกกก ภาพมีการปรับแต่ง graphic ในเกมไปค่อนข้างเยอะ (ในทางที่ดีนะ) HUD ดูโล่งและง่ายขึ้นมามาก ที่สำคัญคือมี minimap มาให้บวกกับมี mark ใน minimap ทำให้รู้ว่าเรามาจากห้องไหน อันนี้ดีมากกันคนหลงไปได้เยอะ ที่ต้องชมเลยก็คือตัวละครนี่แหละ หน้าตัวละครและเสื้อผ้ามีความเป็นธรรมชาติมากขึ้น แต่ละตัวดูสวยหล่อขึ้นมาเป็นกอง

ด้านของเนื้อเรื่องในภาคนี้จะมีความเล่าเป็นเส้นตรงมากกว่าภาคก่อน ทำให้เข้าใจเนื้อเรื่องได้ไวและง่าย แต่ก็เต็มไปด้วยความน่าค้นหาของตัวละครเอกใหม่ในภาคนี้ (nero)

gameplay ภาคนี้โคตรมันส์ เหมือนทีมงานเก็บรายละเอียด feedback จากภาคก่อนๆมาดี การต่อคอมโบของภาคนี้เลยโคตรมันส์โคตรสนุก เจอศัตรูทีไรก็อยากวิ่งไปหาตลอดอะ ข้อสำคัญอีกข้อของภาคนี้คือมันมีให้เลือกระดับความยากแบบละเอียดแล้ว คือถ้าคุณอยากดื่มด่ำกับเนื้อเรื่องก็เล่นความยากระดับ Human (ผมเปรียบเหมือน Easy) ไปเลย ถ้าอยากได้ความท้าทายก็ต้องปลดล็อกความยากโดยเล่นจบในระดับความยากน้อยไปมาก เริ่มจาก Devil Hunter (ผมเปรียบเหมือน Normal) ขึ้นไปเรื่อยๆ ซึ่งข้อนี้ทำให้ภาคนี้เหมาะกับผู้เล่นใหม่เป็นอย่างมาก ผมแนะนำให้เริ่มเล่นจากภาคนี้เลย ถ้าไม่สนใจเรื่องความสัมพันธ์กับตัวละครอะนะ

ส่วนที่หักคะแนนไปมาจากผมเองที่คาดหวังไปเองว่าจะมีเนื้อเรื่องแยก แบบเล่าในมุมมองของอีกตัวละครหนึ่งแต่ก็ยังอยู่ในเหตุการณ์เดียวกัน ซึ่งดันกลายเป็นแค่การเลือกตัวละครอื่นมาเล่นเป็นตัวเอกของเรื่องเฉยๆ Mission เหมือนเดิมเป๊ะ

สรุป - ที่ผมพูดเรื่องความละเอียดเป็นแค่การยกตัวอย่างมาเปรียบเทียบเฉยๆนะครับ ภาค 1-3 มีแบบ HD collection เล่น 1080p ได้เหมือนกัน โดยรวมผมมองว่าเป็นภาคที่เป็นมิตรสำหรับผู้เล่นใหม่นะ ใครไม่เคยเล่นสามารถมาลองเล่นดูได้ ภาค 1-3 มันต้องอาศัยความอดทนและความอยากเอาชนะเยอะหน่อย ภาค 4 นี้เลยจะตอบโจทย์กับผู้เล่นหลายประเภทหน่อย

138846029.review:
[h1]Half SSStylish, half Dull[/h1]
[b]The good parts:[/b]
The whole first part of the game is pretty awesome, Dante and Nero have really good chemistry and are both really fun to play as, the music is amazing as always, the cutscenes are up there with DMC3 in terms of quality, the cheese carries over from 3, the story is meh but is redeemed by the characters (except a few that I'll get to), the level design is good but it doesn't compare to DMC1 and DMC3's level design and the bosses are really fun to fight as Nero, now if the game had ended at about the 6 or 7hour mark, it would be at least an SS, sure a little short, but still great. However, this is a 10-hour game.
[b]The bad parts:[/b]
In the second half of the game, you play as Dante.... in a game that has enemies made for Nero, this makes combat feel off and some bosses are much easier or much harder (and yes, you fight the same bosses without any changes to their moveset except Nico's dad and Nero's adopted brother I think), Lady becomes fan service just like Trish (this thankfully gets fixed in DMC5) and the cherry on top of this shit cake, is that the final boss is ass too. This half of the game was obviously rushed.
[h1]Overall I recommend DMC4, I think it could have been up there with DMC3 and 5 as the best games in the DMC franchise but sadly due to being rushed ended up being just Crazy.[/h1]

I've 100%'d DMC1, maxing out health and DT, then S-ranking every mission on DMD.
I've completely filled out both Dante and Vergil in DMC3, and beaten Bloody Palace.

I dropped this game halfway through Dante's missions, skipped ahead to DMC5, liked that way more, then came back to this and finished it because I'm a glutton for punishment.

This campaign is the single greatest prank ever pulled on Dante as a character, and I don't even like Dante. Every enemy is an annoyance, highlighting just how useless his options are. Gilgamesh is his only real weapon. Everything else feels like a pool noodle.

This game is so good and it had the potential to be my favorite DMC game. However it falls apart when you have to replay the same levels twice and beat all of the same bosses twice (It's even worse if you play as Vergil since you have to beat the same bosses three times whereas if you play Nero/Dante or Trish/Lady you at least fight the bosses with different characters to get some variety)

What I absolutely love about this game though is how replayable it is and how many characters you can play as. You have Nero, Dante, Vergil, Lady and Trish. 138423220.review:
This game is fine. 

I think personally out of the DMC games I have played (1, 3, and now 4) this is the most whatever. I'm excluding 2 because that game sucks way more but I'm not allowing professionals.

Lets start with the pros:
I think the combat is really good in Nero's campaign. I think devil bringer is a very cool concept and the ways you can extend combos on smaller mobs makes the fights less monotonous, and the special moves on bigger boys is always nice to see.

I think the concept of story is pretty good with how instead of these religious people worshipping an angel or something, it's a demon. I enjoy that idea how you have a very basic religion and slowly you uncover the dark folds you aren't meant to see.

Dante's combat is also good with style-switching being a great idea since in 3 the single style you get until you can switch at a statue really promotes a boring system of mainly using only 1 style.

I think the upgrades are cool and a good few of them actually have cool impacts in fights.

Agnus is a cool antagonist, and Credo is a cool psuedo-protag for the short time he has.

And that's all I can think of! Now onto the cons:

Nero and pretty much all of the beginning character designs are REALLY basic and feel more like basic JRPG party members than DMC characters, it lacks it's sense of identity and it even shows with some of the other designs like Dante (why does he have cowboy boots or whatever those are?)

Even though I spoke of how Dante's combat was fun, it's too short lived since you basically just do a reverse of Nero's journey with few upgrades, and you never really get the time to use them.

Bosses in this game are atrocious. There never feels like there's a point where they get good. You beat them relatively easily as Nero, then do the same with Dante. 

Speaking of boss fights, who gave the okay on the Sanctus fights? The first fight wasn't fun, THE SAVIOR FIGHT WAS A SLOGFEST, and the second fight inside the savior is just as boring except Sanctus gains some bullshit homing sword attack that basically kills you after spending your time trying to break a shitty forcefield and actually HIT the cunt. 

Part of playing something like DMC is to have a fight that engages you and actually challenges you, NONE OF THESE THINGS HAPPEN HERE.

Side note: I know there's a second phase. I couldn't be fucked to even take the time to beat the first phase.

The landscape makes no sense. You want me to believe that Nero goes through an abandoned mineshaft and just shows up at a massive ice castle? Sure whatever. But then you want me to believe he goes through another and winds up in a FUCKING JUNGLE??? 

I know DMC3 had very similar fuckery with it's tower, but it wasn't nearly as bad at all here. in 3 you could be like "yeah it's weird but the tower is really big" here it's just plain silly.

Overall, I can see why capcom wanted to reboot after this game, it's all over the place and wants to do more than it has. If they stuck to more stylized designs, potentially made the game a bit longer, and made the bosses better, there would be a really great game here. Too bad there isn't and it came out in like 2008 with SE coming out in 2015.

Decent game, but do not expect much, this game does not have it.

138038075.review:
Честно говоря, рекомендовать эту игру достаточно сложно, я бы поставил какую-нибудь серую оценку, будь такая возможность. 
Если в кратце, игра была бы для меня худшей в серии, если бы не существование DMC2.

Геймплей:
Игра начинается за Нейро, слабо отличающегося от данте персонажа (хотя, если так подумать, он как раз напоминает данте из 2 части). Честно говоря, когда я играл в неё будучи подростком, я думал, что это и есть Данте... 
Персонаж был явно сделан, чтобы облегчить вхождение в серию новичков, потомчно его способности позволяют довольно эффективно перебивають многие атаки противников, чего нельзя сказать о Данте. Геймплей выглядит не очень эффектно, но тем немене врагов рубить всё также интересно, пусть и новой протагонист выглядит слабо на фоне своих (в плане харизмы и мувсета) предшественников.
Данте. Не знаю, какой умник подумал, что это будет хорошая идея забирать у него базовые двжиения, позволяющие ему быстро сближаться с врагами на начальном этапе  [spoiler](особенно учитывая, что мы видели в самой игре на что он способоен) [/spoiler]. Всё потому, что противники здесь отскакивают почти от любомго удара, и если за Неро это проблема леко решается, то за Данте, без прокачки, нет. Из-за этого факта, после того, как нам передают его под управление, на фоне Неро он кажется неуклюжим, слабым и неповоротливым. Однако, по мере прокачки и получения нового оружия, игра за Данте становится именно тем, за что многие любят DMC. Ты начинаешь выбивать просто шикарные комбо и на экране это выглядит крайней эффектно. Это ещё не говоря про противников уходящих за стены, иногда нужно было отходить на другой конец арены, чтобы эти твари наконец выползли из стен, они каждый раз сбивали динамику происходящего (странным образом за Данте их убивать было куда быстрее и приятнее).
Боссы. Да, они не плохи. Но сражаться сими три раза? Да, в DMC 1 было тоже самое, но, простите, в каком году вышла игра? И если уж на то пошло, там хотя бы немного изменялся мувсет и сами арены, здесь же ты три бл раза дерёшься с ними на одной и той же локации. И если бы не отличия в том, за кого играешь, эти бои были бы ещё более унылыми.
К слову, мне показалось, что за Данте убивать боссов было куда проще и (что не мало важно) интереснее.

Сюжет:
Просто какая-то пафосная кабала. Только появление Данте, а в дальнейшем и катсцены с ним, эту тягомотину спасают, без него весь сюжет хотелось бы только быстрее проскипать.

Геймдизайн и взиуал:
Пожалуй, с обоих этих аспектов это худшая часть в серии, даже на фоне DMC2, в которой тоже был бэктрекинг (впрочем, как и во всей серии), но в 2 там хотя бы изменялись локаци, на которые ты возвращался, в других частях ты открывал новые пути прохода и т.п. Здесь же ничего подобного нет: сначала ты идёшь туда, потом сюда по тем же корридорам. Каждая локация абсолютно унылая, блеклая и не интересная. Даже в DMC2 было хотя бы парочку атмосферных мест, не говоря уже про остальных. В купе того, что мы ещё и по несколько раз дерёмся бл с каждым босом, в какой-то момент это начинает немного разражать. И разрабочтики, похоже, это также понимали, поэтому дали нам под управление Данте, а потом и Неро с несколько изменённым мувсетом. Впрочем, ситуацию это спасло лишь отчасти.
Добавляется к бектрекингу и убогая локация с лесом, в которой в куча рандома, вынуждающего проходить одни и теже корридоры по нескольку раз. Более того, здесь буквально есть кубик который мы бросам, хотя его легко прочитать чтобы выбить нужную цифру, но сам факт наличия подобной не нужной механики вызывает вопросы.

Итого:
В моей памяти игра сохранилась куда лучше. Однако пройдя уже все части DMC, для меня эта игра стала разочарованием. Блеклые локации, убогие второстепенные персонажи и такой же сюжет. Но прекрасный Данте и увлекательная боёвка, пусть и не без огрехов.

This game is a slight departure from the previous DMC trilogy because unlike the previous games Dante is no longer the main character. The new main character is Nero who may a bit of a decisive character as he lacks the charisma and charm that Dante had and honestly just isn't as funny. Furthermore, Nero has a completely different set of weapons and combos that are simpler making them better for newer players, but not as engaging for experienced players. This can be a make or break for some as you are stuck with Nero until the end of the game where you get to play as Dante again. The big selling point I'd say for this game is the gameplay which has improved upon the third games combat making it even better. I recommend this to anyone interested in getting into Devil May Cry as this is the start of Nero's story. This means you don't really need to play the previous games to understand the story.

137536449.review:
Devil May Cry 4 is good, but not as good as some of the other games in the series and it also might be the hardest sell of the series on Steam.

DMC 4 has its fair share of problems. The story is nothing special, the camera, not being fully locked and angled nor fully player controlled - being a hybrid between the two of sorts, is not good, ruining the experience in a lot of encounters. The game is also quite short unless you plan on playing all the characters. You still get your dosage of insane cutscene action but the fights, even with a much better combat than in DMC 1-3, leave much to be desired.

When it came out it no doubt looked the best and had the best combat in the entire series, but DMC 5 came out a few years ago. A game which is better in every department and is also similarily priced for some odd reason.

If you'd like to buy another DMC game, get this one for sure. It goes on sale sometimes and on sale it's quite easy to recommend. However. If you don't really crave for more DMC and just want the best - get DMC 5. You will have a much better time.

137084743.review: Hey kiddo! you are missing the fun in here!

137017618.review:
Oh boy, this game is a rough one.
Let's start with the good:
Nero is a new character introduced to the series and he is hella fun. He has a unique combat style based on grabbing and beating the shit out of demons with his buster arm. He has a sword that revs like an engine that you can do special fire attacks with if you time it right and a revolver that shoots 2 bullets. Nero is a very simple character but an incredibly fun one too! His DT is one of the most unique in the series and is very awesome, plus the buster animation on bosses while in DT are godlike.

Dante is also extremely fucking cool in this game and the full weapon wheel plus the style switching system is truly revolutionary for the series. His weapons take a while to get used to compared to the other games and are a bit weird to combo into eachother but I have played the game only once so maybe I just suck,

The combat, in general, is really smoking good.....BUT

THE BAD:
This game is filled to the brim with problems. THEY ARE EVERYWHERE.

The enemies suck. I can't put it any other way. When playing as Nero it is not that big of an issue since you can just buster them as a solution to any problem. When you play as Dante tho, HOLY SHIT. Almost every enemy either ignores your attacks,  perma blocks them or just keeps running/teleporting away. While Dante is way more powerful than Nero, he actually feels worse to play, because the enemies were never meant for him in the first place.

What do I mean by this?

This game is so blatantly unfinished.
You fight the main bosses not once, not twice....BUT 3 DIFFERENT FUCKING TIMES. WHO THOUGHT OF THIS???? The bosses in general are pretty generic but have great buster animations, with the exception of Credo which might be one of the best fights in the series. 
The worst part and the DEFINITIVE PROOF this game is not finished is that Mister Dante has no unique levels and has to replay trough all of Nero's levels.......BUT IN REVERSE. He only gets one unique bossight and it is one of the worst bosses ever made in DMC history: THE SAVIOR. Fuck this thing.

The puzzles in this game are just shit and kill momentum, there is no fun to using beyblades to break walls or spinning a dice to get trough a door and I especially dislike the shitty platforming with spikes everywhere .  I like puzzles and platforming! Good puzzles and good platforming, not this shitty excuse to artificially extend the game's length. 


The story
The story is there??? I mean it's not necessarily bad....but nobody inside the game really seems to care about it either?!?!? Why is anything happening? Why does the evil pope guy try to make people believe he is a hero by summoning demons to attack them and then be saved by him? I thought the church already controlled the entire city??
This story can be summed up as : Dante goes to vacation and kills a cringe religious group with his nephew.
The characters are pretty forgettable, except for Dante and Nero. Credo is cool but doesn't do that much and everyone else is just an evil villain/demon or evil scientist. Kyrie is also just a generic love interest.

So why do I recommend this game?

Because the combat is that good. 

If you are looking for an action game just to kill things,you will enjoy DMC 4 a lot! The game is also very replayable liike most DMCs with additional difficulties that change up the gameplay and Lady, Trish and Vergil waiting for you to try them out. If you want anything more than just fun and fast stylish combat you won't find it here I'm afraid.

Esto fue terrible para mí, ya que ya era bastante difícil para mí pasar tiempo con mi hijo, ya que él siempre sale con sus amigos o simplemente mira videos en Tiktok. Así que decidí crear una cuenta de Steam y comprar este juego para ver si podía jugar junto a él. Cargué el juego, hice el tutorial pero estaba atascado en lo que se suponía que debías hacer. Desde entonces, este juego ha acercado a mi hijo y a mí nuevamente y ahora también pasamos tiempo juntos fuera de la casa. Este juego me recordó que hay diversión en todo, y nos ha traído tanto a mí como a mi hijo muchos recuerdos felices.

First of all, the game is really good and fun. However, it does have its share of problems.
First, the camera is your worst enemy. It stops rotating every time it hits a wall. Btw, trees and rocks count as walls.
Second, the game has problems comunicating what it wants the player to do. In an effort to not hold your hand, it gives scarse information and as a result, most of the time you don't know where to go or what to do. Plus, some bosses want you to do really cryptic stuff (like the final phase of the final boss).
Third, the lock-on sucks. Through the entirety of my first playthrough I couldn't hit the enemies I wanted to. Tried every option available with the same result.
Fourth, levels and bosses are recycled to the max. I know that by now it is a staple of Dmc, but it wouldn't hurt to have new locations and more enemy variety.
Despite its problems, the game offers great gameplay and tons of replay value. It's not as good as 1 and 3, but I don't regret playing it.

136789066.review:
[h1]I already wrote a review for DMC4: Regular Edition before this game came out. You should go read that one if you want to know about the base game, this just covers the new stuff[/h1]

This game is a collection of upgrades and two slight downgrades:

Adds 3 new playable characters characters - This alone makes the upgrade worth it
Makes the graphics a little prettier
The "speed" ability that allows your character to sprint kicks in much quicker, which is extremely convenient for moving around outside combat.
Increased rate of collecting proud souls, which unlock abilities. This makes the grind far less tedious.
New outfits for Dante and Nero
The gameplay changes, such as the proud souls rate and speed buff can actually be reverted to how they were in the original game with a code, if you are a purist.

The unfortunate drawbacks:
Motion blur that CAN NOT be turned off.
One save file. Only a problem for someone like me who wanted to try a playthrough on the hardest difficulty on a fresh save file, but objectively speaking going from multiple save files to just one is a downgrade.

DMC4 is really frustrating in how half baked it is and the special edition only makes me sad knowing there's a lot of potential that DMC5 goes hard at when all the changes made we're just adding characters that still struggle with problems that only Nero and Vergil are equiped to deal with. I'm gonna hit yes on the recommend if you wanna playthrough the entire series, but if you're the type of person who's okay with watching a playthrough and moving on to better games in a series so you have context for things that move over between entries and storylines then I'd suggest you just open a new tab and go on YouTube.
