135195248.review:
The pain of such an amazing combat engine being located in such an inconsistent, unfinished game is something that would sting way more if not for the fact that DMC 5 exists and apparently takes all the cool things even further than this one does. This of course doesn't change the fact that this is still an unfortunate step down from DMC 3 that clearly suffered a lot from a lack of development time along with having a plethora of weird gimmicky ideas that only serve to drag down the overall experience. On the other hand though, I cannot think of many examples this is a prime example of a game that's carried so hard by one element being insanely good that it can make you somewhat overlook the fact that almost everything surrounding it doesn't really do anything for you.

The movesets of both Nero and Dante are really sick in this game, Nero playing in a very different way that appeals to me perfectly, and Dante showcasing just how you can cram even more avenues for chaining absurd combos together into a system that already had a lot of that. Nero's greater focus on air mobility and enemy juggling just appeals to me perfectly, giving the player enough tools to stay airborne for way longer without having to become a god at the game to do so. The way the vast majority of his moves flow into each other so cleanly further adds to this and provides a certain sense of smoothness to his fighting style compared to the more jagged, visceral edge that defines Dante's playstyle. Speaking of Dante's playstyle, it absolutely rules here with the amount of tools you get at your disposal along with the absolutely deranged things you can chain together if you really want to get the most out of his capabilities. While I'm not good enough to take full advantage of it, the ability to change styles on the fly is nonetheless insanely cool and would make me want to keep trying to improve if not for the fact that actually interacting with the obstacles thrown your way are just not very engaging.

Crafting such an in-depth, complex and fun combat engine and then making its only use cases 7 levels which are entirely reused, complete with enemies clearly not designed for Dante and anything new added being the worst thing ever is heartbreaking. The gimmicks introduced for this latter portion of the game are never anything that come across as interesting at all, with any challenges they introduce stemming more from being inconvenienced than providing an interesting shakeup to the formula. It's obviously made worse by the fact that these extra painful gimmicks are, as stated, located in stages that you've literally already fully gone through as Nero and are now just backtracking through for the 2nd half of the game. The enemies also suck to fight a lot of the time, with a lot of them not really having clear and simple counters with Dante, despite the absurd power he packs. This leads to a situation where each encounter takes place on one of two extremes, either everything is eviscerated in seconds, or you're stuck having to do something really finicky and awkward, grinding the pacing to a halt.

Maybe I'd have been fine with this if not for the fact that it's not as if the level design was especially engaging the first time around anyway. Everything just feels a bit too small and lacking in any real setpieces or even atmosphere in a lot of cases that really made me love how 1 and 3 handled its stages. A lot of the extra mechanics and "puzzles" don't really feel good either, with a lot of them either feeling weirdly artificial or just janky (not in a fun way) to use. The gyro blades especially come to mind with the latter issue, where the player just had to push these big spinning blades through destructible walls and all that, but actually moving them where you wanted was a constantly imprecise pain. The dice sections also are just bad, no further explanation needed.

That said, one other thing I actually did like about the game was the narrative and cutscenes, as was expected. Whether it's the first half being dead serious but in this really goofy way mostly where everything feels super over the top, or the 2nd half which is just a lot of Dante being Dante but to an even greater extent than usual, it's just a great time. In the end it's really just like, DMC 4 is damn lucky that just swinging a sword around in it is one of the coolest things ever and that Dante is who he is, because these two things are really the main things stopping me from disliking the game. I was going to mess around with some of the other playable characters in this afterwards, given how cool I was finding certain aspects so fun for a while, but the 2nd half of the game really, really hurt my desire to replay this anytime soon, even if I'll still say that I enjoyed it to an extent regardless.

7/10

(actual game time is 2 hours)
Avoid this.
I haven't played the other Devil May Cry games, except the reboot which I recommend. Devil May Cry 4 is bad, not as bad as Devil May Cry 3 which I couldn't even get past the first boss. But still bad, suffers with different problems.
To get the good out the way, the graphics are alright, the cutscenes are insanely good rendered in game, although there is an overabundance of gameplay cutscenes (Room locking and stuff) for some reason, to the point of not enjoying them. Some parts of the combat are okay, but it feels underwhelming.

Now the bad, and there's a lot of it. The story and dialogue. I felt like there wasn't anything being explained. Having never played the first three stories, I had no clue what was going on here. I also assumed because it was a later game it would be more accessible, but no. Nothing was explained. There's barely any dialogue so the world feels empty (This is objective). 
The tutorials whilst okay, they're not great, there's also an automatic combo system which is nice, but for some reason I think this disables the actual use of combos and actual moves? I wasn't able to dodge at all despite the game showing me how to (Hold R1, Press A and move left or right). Then the combat doesn't really hit any strong notes. The audio design is fine, but the style points system makes no sense, and the enemies feel extremely tanky despite this being on easy difficulty. 

And now the arguably worst part that made me stop playing. It's open world but you can't return to some areas after a certain point? Even more confusing is, there's no direction. You enter these random door areas, to find items or puzzles, but there often isn't any, or it's locked behind another thing (A problem I had with the reboot too, to be clear, all this is). The lack of direction, or just, objective markers, made this completely unplayable for me. I somehow had to magically get this Gyro power thing to this one place, but there is none around to do it? so...??? 
It's actually hard to see how this has a 90% positive review score. This feels so undercooked. Also the settings menu is terrible, and the game requires a gamepad to be playable (they didn't bother changing the control scheme for Keyboard).

134738377.review:
The game has great game-play, yet it's story is a bit lack luster and it's design did Dante himself dirty.

Game-play first, DMC4 has a new playable character, Nero, and his combat is simple but fun. Nero is really beginner friendly as he does not have styles like Dante and no other weapons besides his sword Red Queen and his gun Blue Rose. It may seem like Nero is boring to play, but his defining feature is his Devil Bringer, which using the right trigger, Nero uses a kind of finisher type move, with it having a cool animation once executed. It does not actually insta-kill enemies (Besides a couple fodder enemies) but it deals good damage and can even be used on bosses. It also acts as a grappling hook for level traversal and even combat, being able to grab enemies and close the distance. His devil trigger is literally a stand, but it has a cool design plus adds new Devil Bringer animations so that's nice.

Dante has some great changes too, in DMC3 the player was limited to just 1 style, with leveling up being difficult when it can take half a play through just to level it up to max. In DMC4, Dante can switch to all of his styles in a flash and has a 5th style called Dark Slayer he acquires later on in the game. Plus, leveling up styles are now tied with red orbs, so leveling them up is easier to do. In my opinion, DMC3 had the superior arsenal for Dante, but DMC4's array of weapons aren't so bad themselves, Rebellion being the basic sword, Gilgamesh being the hand to hand combat weapon, and Lucifer which summons explosive red spikes. Rebellion is nothing new, having all it's move set from previous games. Gilgamesh is a lot like Beowulf, even sharing some moves it had in DMC3, but it has some of it's own special moves. Lucifer is a cool idea, but its move set is lacking in variety and doesn't really feel all that nice to use. Dante may not have the best weapons in this game, but his style switching is a massive improvement and really adds more depth to playing him.

There are other playable characters, those being Lady, Trish, and Vergil. They don't have any new levels, but the option to play them is at least there. However, the biggest flaw this game has, is the fact that Dante doesn't even get his own levels. What I mean by this is that once you are given control of Dante, you literally just go backwards through the entire game, playing all the levels Nero did, facing 3 of the same bosses Nero already fought (This is how Dante gets his devil arms, but it is still weird to not give him is own bosses), and the final fight is fought with Dante, but the final fight is pretty trash comparable to the likes of Arkham in the last game. Nero may be the main focus of the game this time around, but to not give The Legendary Demon Hunter is own levels in the main campaign is pretty lazy and lowers the experience of playing as him. Bloody Palace though makes Dante worth playing for sure.

There are a lot of enemy types that are WAY too annoying to fight unless you spam a certain move. The enemies are okay though but it is just annoying that there are so many that make the game less enjoyable. The bosses are a step down compared to DMC3, but most of them are good for the most part. Although some bosses seem a lot easier as Nero than Dante but that's mostly due to Nero's Devil Bringer. The Savior is the final boss of the game, and is pretty bad. It's designed to incorporate platforming, but it just feels like a chore to go to one platform to hit this specific part and then repeat that like 6 times.

Now for the story, it is pretty lack luster. Introducing a whole new cast of characters are great, and all the characters have their own motivations and kind of have personalities. Nero is basically just a Dante rip off in this game, but thankfully he has his own moments that can't be performed with Dante. Nero's love interest, Kyrie, is a pretty stale and under developed character, barely speaking even though it seems like something should be said in that moment, and what she does say is pretty bare bones and generic. Dante is his usual self, although he is a lot more mature and professional. The actual story I won't talk about too much for the sake of spoilers, but it is pretty simple and again, lack luster with a few cool moments in between, the introduction of Nero and his development moments are easily the highlight of the story.

Overall, Good game-play, good bosses for the most part, lack luster story, and is worth a play.

134732331.review:
I'm 10 missions into this and I gotta say, it's awful compared to DMC3. No matter how good it is after this, it's not worth a buy simply based on how incompetent the general design is. To put some bullet points out:

- Camera is just terrible, always at a bad angle, never frames fights properly.
- Enemies attack from offscreen constantly. This was NOT a problem in DMC3, the only time it ever happened to me was when an Enigma began firing but the camera angle changed. Here? Every enemy does it.
- Nero's "delay" inputs on ground are like twice as long as DMC3 Dante's and it's a giant pain when trying to combo. Seriously, you need to wait like three quarters of a second to do the RQ combo 2 and 3. It's absurd.
- Bosses universally bad so far, Dante in particular is just the laziest input-reading crap I've ever seen. He even has iframes in neutral when you're not supposed to hit him, and can inexplicably ignore damage from things like Nero's level 3 charge shots when he feels like it. Just bleh.
- Two enemy types that are tolerable: Scarecrows and the basic Angelos, everything else is some variety of cancer. Even the basic Angelos are annoying because of the shield and their offscreen attacks, but they're at least slow enough that they're not a pain to kill.
- - In particular, the Mephistos and Fausts are genuinely the worst enemies I've ever seen in one of these games or anything in the genre.
- - Also, every enemy has way too much health and it makes combat unsatisfying. Know how many hits it takes to kill a basic Pride Hell in DMC3 on normal with Rebellion? Like 5-6 depending on your moves. How many to kill a scarecrow here? Try 10+ unless you're hitting exceed on every move with Nero. Yes it makes combos easier, but at the same time it makes you feel WEAK.
- Level design is boring and sometimes outright confusing. They literally had to add a sprint because of all the time you'd waste running around at normal speed. The game also really wants to be Zelda sometimes and every time it tries to I feel my soul dying.
- [strike]Visual style pales in comparison to any other game in the series yes even DMC2. It's just boring to look at. It reminds me of Darksiders 1, but with less visual detail.[/strike] I finished DMC5, it's even worse in this respect, so much so that I actually think 4's environments are good in comparison. So, I can't honestly say this anymore.
- Not being able to grapple with lockon is the dumbest control decision I've ever seen. There are literally forward+input combos specifically to avoid needing to fumble the lockon constantly mid-combo.
- Speaking of lockon, it sucks. Every time I hit R1 and there are more than 2-3 enemies onscreen it will always pick the enemy I am not intending to attack. Even sometimes when there are just two enemies, it decides that the one WAY over there is the one I want to attack and not the one right in front of me.
- Sometimes Nero will just decide to run in the literal opposite of the direction I'm holding on the stick, even adjusting his angle to continue moving the wrong way if I tilt the stick a bit. This isn't a controller problem because I can see on my second monitor that the controller is giving the correct input. Sometimes this even happens in combat.

etc. etc. I could go on and I'm barely halfway through the normal story mode. Do not pay for this, not even on sale.

EDIT:
Beat the rest, it's even worse overall. Only good part is Dante when the camera works and the enemies aren't built specifically for Nero. Everything else is trash. Good god those last two levels. I even knew the dice trick going in (using devil bringer on it always lands it on the number it was showing when you hit it) and mission 19 felt like a test of patience. Not because it was hard, but because it took FOREVER. Both of Sanctus' fights suck too. Jesus what were they thinking on this. I think the gameplay gave me brain damage because I can't even remember the story, gonna watch through it on youtube again before playing V.

Do not buy this. I don't care what DMC superfans say about the "technicality" of this game and how it has the "highest skill ceiling". The story mode sucks, the characters aren't fun except for Dante sometimes, any non-hardcore player will be continually annoyed by the incompetent controls and design, and worst of all it's not even really a challenge on normal like 1 or 3. I died one time to lasers because I got juggled for literally seven hits in a row while laughing at the absurdity. Despite all the offscreen attacks, despite all the crap controls, despite the Blitz trying its hardest to be a figurative gameplay tumor in the 2 times I encountered it, nothing really got my blood pumping.

Compare to DMC3, where I died at least once on every boss but Worm, Vergil 2, and Arkham (because I used items on Arkham since he's about on par with the bosses from this game). Where the bosses were almost all engaging enough that I at least cared to learn their mechanics. Where even regular enemies were sometimes a bit scary in the beginning due to their numbers and damage. Where the story was interesting from the start. Where when I finished my first run, I went "Damn I can't wait to go back to this after 4 and 5".

For this game? I'd return it if I could. I paid $8CDN and I feel like I was ripped off. Just buy 3 and play that. I hear 5 is great too. Gonna install that next to try to wipe this one from my mind.

134536309.review:
[h1] What the hell is this? [/h1]
[h3] - Dante upon seeing trees. [/h3]

[b] Devil May Cry 4 Special Edition [/b] is a 2015 re-release of 2008's Devil May Cry 4. Despite that date, this game has a worse PC port than DmC: Devil May Cry(which came out in 2013, two years earlier), and in fact might be the worst PC port I have ever played. This is a port so bad, I am providing this review with 12 MINUTES of play time. I only got past the first MISSION before I decided "nah fuck this game". I generally judge various aspects of the game in my reviews, but 12 minutes isn't enough to judge. 

NOTE: I have decided to change some shit, you'll figure out which below, and I'll try to get through this game. Money was used to acquire the game, I'll play the game dammit.

[h2] The port [/h2]
This port has various issues with it. Actually fucking stupid issues that DmC did not have. For example, the game will randomly stutter, which I don't think should be occurring in this game on a system that can run games like Modern Warfare II and DOOM Eternal.

Now the elephant in the room; the controls. In DmC, the menus are keyboard only but that is countered with the GOD-TIER in-game mouse and keyboard controls. Here, the mouse works in menus(with weird implementation), but the mouse is outright NOT supported in game. And the default keyboard controls themselves are weird. Space isn't even to jump, it is to lock on. To jump, you press something like K, which is right next to I, the default melee attack bind. Sure, you can rebind these, but there's five fucking characters there are controls for, so you'll need to rebind for EVERY SINGLE ONE. It is very clear this was made for controllers(and I do have one myself so I could just pull one up if I wanted to, however not every PC player has one), but so was DmC, and that game had really good PC controls. Furthermore, the tutorial prompts only show the Xbox 360 buttons, not even the keyboard ones.

[h2] Verdict [/h2]

I hereby declare Devil May Cry 4: Special Edition as 
[h3] MAYBE GOOD GAME, SHIT PORT. [/h3]

132688657.review:
One of my favourite DMC's, I orignally played it on Xbox360, so I was excited to play it with higher resolutions/graphics settings etc, however the DMC team over at Capcom seem persistent to give you blurry AA in the case of DMC5 (TAA) and forced depth of field and motion blur with DMC4 with no option to disable them, whatever the case your getting blurry image quality whether you like it or not with the DMC team, I would also expect the same with the next DMC game too.

It's little cheap having to fight the same boss twice and have lots of backtracking with reused levels, also if you previously purchased items and use them (Purchased from the statue or found in a level) you will have to start over right from the start of a level without those items, same is true if continuing from a checkpoint, you only get one chance to use them despite having to fight all the same enemies/bosses again if you die, which is only that way to extend the game, if we wanted extra challenge to begin with we could just not purchase the items.

UPDATE: you fight the same bosses THREE TIMES which is not only frustrating but really cheap that they could not come up any new ones, they even make you roll a dice to fight the same bosses you fought, if the dice lands on a position that's not white you have to fight hordes of enemies to fight the boss and if you die during the boss fight you will have to roll the dice again.

Based on this I do not recommend the game.

In saying that the first half of DMC4 is good despite the mentioned issues, but maybe wait for a sale and expect plenty of frustration with the second half if you do decide to buy it.

132203110.review:
DMC 4 is a good game, fun game at that, but the port is good for most part....do note that unlike in DMC5, you will need a controller for this one cause this game doesn't register a mouse and keyboard controls are pretty bad. 

While this game is pretty good and characters and the story are cool and all, it has some major flaws.

• Once you switch to Dante, get ready to backtrack through the same levels you passed as Nero and get ready to fight the same 3 bosses again. I honestly don't know why they did. Almost the 2nd half of this game was just backtracking to the start of the game pretty much.

• Some enemies are beyond annoying and are just "cheap" to break your combo, like the stupid invisible plant mine thing that can swallow you and send you to the shadow realm or whatever, like it's not even a challenge, just a cheap annoyance you gotta watch out for.

• Fighting the same 3 bosses, 3 f*cking times. Those hellgate bosses you are forced to fight 3 times just felt like developers were a bit lazy when it came to that part. Overgrown frog was the worst out of the 3 btw.

• Lady is kinda boring to play, which is disappointing to me personally because she is like my 2nd favorite character, next to Vergil, and when I tried playing her, I almost fell asleep. At least she isn't boring to play as much as V from DMC5, but still. I feel like they could've made her combat more fun. 

Despite this, this is still a pretty good DMC game and it is worth playing. Combat is still fun and stylish.

132167212.review: I first played devil may cry 5 and beat it twice and wanted more, I was pleasantly surprised when I found out the combat in this game with Nero and Dante is just as fun and feels fundamentally the same for someone who is a casual player like myself. I heard the levels aren't good but I actually enjoyed them and they mostly had enough exploration that I got lost sometimes. The way the levels have various breakable objects that give you money for upgrades and the way that beating enemies gives you points for skill upgrades reminds me of the feeling I get while playing my favourite CastleVania games and breaking candles for hearts and money. The castles and haunted forests and caves fit well with that series as well. I saw a review that mentioned the best way to play this game is by not using healing items and I agree, it doesn't send me too far back when I die and the game is too easy for if you use them so I recommend not doing so if you want to be challenged. My issues with this game is that the first levels are boring and you can't save the game half way through a level and the game doesn't tell you how to do some cool things that will really help you out with combat vs some enemies. But it is also fun to play a game that lets you figure out the weaknesses of enemies on your own again. I don't know how to end this review but I don't think anyone will read this far anyways.

131787888.review:
This game is amazing. That's the short way to put it. 
Combat is like nothing before it. Newcomer Nero is surprisingly fun to play. Dante is back and more powerful than ever. Along with three other characters that're unique but really let you reach new heights of character action.

The problem, I'd say, is that the missions tend to run on a bit long. While the areas and camera angles are absolutely stunning (especially for 2008), it's a bit easy to get turned around if you don't know where you're going. There are some frustrating puzzles and enemies (I'll never understand who thought the Dice Roll and Gyro blades were a good idea).  Half-way through the game you have to backtrack through the entire map and fight all the same bosses you did before-- then leading into the second to last boss which is... the worst boss ever. Which then leads into a boss rush where you fight all of the boss (except the best one) for a third time. Then you fight a pretty alright final boss. 

The game... is a mixed bag. But I think it's totally worth it for the full Devil May Cry experience (if you're like me and like to play through all the games in order). As I said before, the combat is something unmatched until the fifth game, Dante being the most versatile action game protag there ever was and Nero being absolutely savage with his Buster take downs. Most of the bosses are great, ESPECIALLY the fight against Credo (that fight alone makes revisiting this game always worth it for me) and the second fight against Dante. The cut-scenes are some of the best we'll ever get in the series.

Worth the buy.

8/10

131429059.review:
Devil May Cry 4 is a fun game but it's very flawed as well.
Story centers this time not around Dante but on a new character Nero which might upset some people not having Dante as the main protagonist,
but it goes well with how Nero get's introduced to the series.

Nero in this game is a bit like DMC3 Dante but more hot headed.
Nero also plays completley different compared to Dante having only 1 weapon his Blue Rose and his sword Red Queen which he revs to give a fire like ability to his sword, that's not all
next to that he has the Devil Bringer, as he is a demon as well his right arm is a demon arm giving him multiple abillites, his arm can do for one called the Buster move, 
he basically grabs the enemies and throws them or smacks them with each enemy having a unique throw or smack animation, he can also use the Buster Move to bosses which gives a whole new move to it,
that also differs from each boss. Nero is also more new player friendly compared to Dante.
Overall i enjoyed Nero as a character and his gameplay alot. 

Now how does Dante do in this game well.......
I'm gonna be honest, Dante in my opinion feels so wasted in this game and that sucks a lot considering his gameplay is amazing and very technical and complex compared to the other DMC games, this is the first game where he can switch styles on the fly having still the OG 4 styles Trickster, Swordmaster, Gunslinger and Royalguard and also 
having [spoiler]Vergil's style Darkslayer giving him access to some of Vergil's moves while wielding the Yamato[/spoiler]. 
Saying all this you're still thinking as to why i feel that Dante is wasted?
He just doesn't fit in this game at all, we get introduced in the beginning that[spoiler] Dante comes out of knowhere and kills the leader of The Order Sanctus,
goes around killing some guards as well, which we later find out that they're actually demons and not just human beings makes us think there is something going behind The Order[/spoiler].
Dante overall in the story doesn't do a lot at all as he basically is a [spoiler]backtracking character actually replaying Nero's missions and fighting his bosses as well (why) and after that to go fight a underwhelming boss in mission 18.
and he also obtains the Devil Arms from the bosses Nero fought which suck imo[/spoiler], 
it's such a downgrade to what his weapons were in DMC3 which just makes playing as Dante with those weapons not so fun to me, he had more viraity in DMC3 with his weapons, 
which he just doesn't have in this game, Rebellion is like the only weapon i can have fun with as Dante with [spoiler]Gilgamesh[/spoiler] being second but also being a downgraded [spoiler]Beowulf[/spoiler].
Overall Dante doesn't do it to much to me in this game, is he fun to play as? Yes, are his weapons fun to play with? No, and it's really sad.

How is the overall game?
Oh boi, so it's definitely not DMC2 level bad by any means, but boi does this game have a lot of flaws.
The missions are decent at best while still fun to play with as Nero, they are just a bothersome to[spoiler] play again as Dante[/spoiler].
Some missions do have some major issues, being the puzzles which are for Nero and only for Nero as well, you got some platforming is this game
where you use your Devil Bringer to grapple to different places, some stuff where you use blades to open a door in mission 3 or crush a closed gate which you have to go through,
or you play a dice game........ yes a dice game where you have to roll the dice in the steps you want to move, some of it being enemy spawns some laser dodging and some where it gives you a lot of red orbs.
Man do i hate that mini game funny thing is that none of these stuff happen when you play as Dante, matter a fact when he approaches the dice mini game [spoiler]he slashes the dice and literally skips it lol[/spoiler].
Those are some puzzles in the missions but now we have the missions themself and eh?? to me the missions feel weird, 
so you are Nero and your target is [spoiler]capturing Dante so you go out in these missions to different places one being a castle and the other in a forrest[/spoiler], you fight some bosses and you move on to next mission? i don't know man the bosses feel like they don't have to be in the story they just feel so disconected, except for some bosses and one boss which is also the best boss in the game lol who you also only get to fight as Nero yay -_-.

Those were the missions, 
how about the story and soundtrack and what about the characters?
The story is decent it's definitely not a DMC3 level story and not even DMC1, funny thing is this game feels like a mix of DMC1 and DMC3 but worse. 
The sad thing is that DMC4 isn't even a finished game hence why [spoiler]you play Nero's missions again as Dante and why the enemies don't feel right to fight against as Dante[/spoiler],
i think you can find a whole story about it on the web of why the game became like this and how it was actually meant to be.
The soundtrack is good i had a lot of enjoyment in Nero's battle theme and Dante's and some boss themes, while also a lot of missions had some interesting ambience like feel to it.
The characters are good like Nero who i really enjoyed a lot in this game, Dante has some cool and funny moments but still a bit lacking storywise,
some of the other characters like Credo and Agnus are also some good characters. Credo being the caring brother of Kyrie and Agnus being a scientist who does science on demons.
Kyrie is also a good close love interest to Nero while still having a damsel in distress like role she is important to Nero's character.
The villain was alright his boss battle being a bit fun as well, after the horrible mission where you do a [spoiler]boss rush with the damned dice game[/spoiler] man i hated that mission what a waste.
Some known characters are also in it like Trish and Lady, while they don't do a lot to the story either, they do something else....


DMC4:Special Edition
That's right, in this version of DMC4 you get to play with three more characters including:
Trish, Lady and Vergil.
How do they play you say?
Trish is a huge upgrade from how she played in DMC2, she is really fun to play with having an insane amount of new moves, wielding Sparda and her guns Luce and Ombre and the [spoiler]Pandora Box that Dante uses[/spoiler].
Lady is fun as well but considering that she is a human her gameplay is alright and is more of a gunslinger having shotguns, pistols and grenades, she also slashes with the Kalina Ann which has a blade attached to it.
Vergil, oh boi it's time to get motivated!
Vergil is an insane step up compared to his playstyle in DMC3, he is so fun to play as and honestly my most played character in this game 
while still having his old weapons from 3 Yamato, Force Edge and Beowulf, they have been updated insanely as they have more moves now then ever before!
His summoning swords are also a lot better then 3 being way more powerfull now, Vergil in this game is so goddamn powerfull it's insane how much care was put to his playstyle.
The newest edition to his style being the Concentration bar, when you actually play as Vergil as intended which means no running or jumping, and being locked on to the enemy
you fill up his Concentration bar which makes you motivated as ever when filling the bar being able to do his ultimate move
The Judgement Cut End.
He also get's a new battle theme that for some reason is only played in his beginning cutscene????? Just why.
There is also something new to this addition a whole new mode named Legendary Dark Knight mode which spaws a ton of enemies in a Son of Sparda like difficulty
have fun with that!.

Oh almost forgot Bloody palace also returns in this game this time having the rounds go single times to 101 instead of 9999 with round skips like DMC2 and DMC3, and it's very fun to play in it as all the playable characters!

Overall my thoughts are it's a fun game but very flawed, would still play sometime
(8.5)

124816249.review:
It's a shame that Devil May Cry 4's campaign is such a rushed mess, and the special edition doesn't do anything to alleviate the repetitiveness of the main campaign. However, the game features one of the finest stylish action combat systems ever made. With the special edition, you now have 3 more playable characters to play with, new character costumes, and a new game mode called "legendary dark knight".

Legendary Dark Knight mode is unlocked right from the beginning, and it's a welcome addition. It increases the enemy count up to 10 times as many, overwhelming you from the get-go. It's different from the normal campaign, instead of methodically taking on each enemy, you're encourage to use as many hard hitting moves as possible. The interesting thing about Devil May Cry 4, due to the quirks and the mechanics of the combat system, is that it is easily one of the most busted games out there. Whether intentional or not, it's the kind of game that lets you straight up kill big bosses with 1 hit. Legendary Dark Knight mode seems to be designed just for the intricacies of the combat system.

With that said, Devil May Cry 4 is not exactly an easy game. Enemies quickly swarm all over you, forcing you to take on each enemy encounter methodically and stylishly. It's not just about quickly killing your enemies, it's about doing as many different combos to your enemies as possible to get high score rankings. The higher rankings you get, the faster you get new weapon movesets or health upgrades.

Really the only thing that brings this game down is the campaign, or rather, the unfinished quality of the campaign. The campaign starts off strong. It leads you through various distinct environments and features probably one of the best boss fights in gaming. You can tell a lot of money and effort went into the first half of the game... and then the game pretty much just copies and pastes that first half into the second half of the game. Even the story is almost non-existent in the second half, it's like the game ran out of budget mid-development and the developers had to quickly scrape something together to have a finished game. 

It's a shame, the story wants to depict angelic, holy figures as evil beings hellbent on destruction. It's an interesting theme but the story just ends up under-cooked due to the half-finished nature of the game.

8/10

124790402.review:
What a sad excuse of a Devil May Cry game. 
It does not have either the seriousness nore the ridiculousness od DMC and DMC 3. 
It does not go to the low points but also does not accomplish the great things of DMC 2. 
It is nothing. Bland and uninspired. Level after leve feel boring and cobbled together with no rhyme and reason. 
And it is severely lacking! 
The first main character does not even get to collect different weapons and such - a staple of DMC games. 
The collecting starts after HALF THE GAME is OVER. WHich is just backtracking of the first half of the game. 

It is all boring and useless. 
Yes, there are Vergil, lady and Trish as playable characters. But they don't have their own missions. They just retread the same level as the main character, doing the same things - without any grounds in the story. They just changed the player model and send you into the same boring levels. 

And as a last thing: They ruined Lady. They turned a character that was powerful - not on par with Dante but she was able to stand her ground - and took all individuality,  both in charakter and in visual style - and turned her into a boring, bland, characterless boob doll. Not a thing about this game rings true. 

FUCK DMC 4. It is actually the worst part in the series. All is worse even than DMC 2

Less fun than DMC3 or even the original DMC IMHO, but still worth playing. You don't get to play as Dante right away, but if you get bored of Nero (like I did) you can always switch to Vergil or Lady without having to complete the game first. Unfortunately, you [i]cannot[/i] play on any difficulty higher than normal on your first playthrough, which is a shame because the game is boringly easy compared to 1 and 3 even on normal mode despite the latter being explicitly targeted towards returning players.

I'm not a big fan of this game but I'd argue that's mostly because I don't like Nero's gameplay – which, unlike my issue with the difficulty, is purely subjective and may actually be the opposite for you, so give it a try if you're interested.

122375470.review:
Its quite a good game, a decent follow up to Devil May Cry 3 and plays mostly the same but with new editions. Definetly a game to pick up, but there are just a few little problems with it.

Firstly the story, it is really bad but not to the extent of Devil May Cry 2 thankfully, it just simply lacks anything cool or motivating to drive you forward. It comes off as very boring and generic. You mainly play as the new protagonist Nero, who from a personality point doesn't offer a lot. He's no dante and doesnt have to be but he acts like every other shonen anime protagonist but can have his fair share of lines every now and then. He is tasked with hunting down dante who kills a pope in his order but you don't even know why? You later find out why but it was typical and expected. Nero has no driving motivations other than a girl he loves known as Kyrie, who offers nothing compared to other female characters like trish and lady. Kyrie is the damsel in distress through and through. The order of the sword is also a interesting antagonistic faction with motives but they are very strange and dont make sense as you progress. Dante is essentially neglected and is shown to have made 0 progress to fighting the big bad boomer. Most of the best moments in the story is when Nero isnt on screen, which is ashame as I do want to like this character but I cannot for now. 

Gameplay is quite fun though. While Nero isn't as complex as dante with his styles and different devil arms, Nero can serve as a more 'friendly' less combo heavy character. He mainly has his sword, the red queen which has the most anime like ability of revving the sword which can have charges on it. however it is mainly good to use when you perform your combos as if you do it idle, it makes gameplay come to a halt and is very boring to play. learn the rev skills and he becomes more fun to play.  His gun is not as good and is more of a situational use. His devil bringer, the skill he mainly has is great for more combos and busters which allow nero to do big damage to his target and even use some of the enemies as a body shield. 

Dante plays great, just like in Devil May Cry 3. He has less weapons than 3 but the weapons themselves arent half bad. I especially like the crazy weapon they added in, Pandora, which is a suitcase that turns into a bow missile launcher, a legit tri barrel missile launcher, a minigun case, a laserbeam and a literal sphere to barrage rockets (though not as cool as it should be). Lucifer is a fun fast needle spawner weapon and Gilgamesh is another variant of the past gauntlet weapons like Ifrit and Beowolf focusing on hard hitting combos and some fast speed combos. In addition, you have the good old fashion rebellion, ebony and ivory and Coyote A, his shotgun. 

With the special edition, you get access to Vergil, who plays the same as the previous title, being more focused on ruthless aggression and speed, spamming summoned swords on one hand, creating sword barriers, cornering them on your enemies, as well as yamato being speedy and fast, force edge being a dual wield and similar to rebellion and of course, Beowolf. Lady is also another playable one, utilizing her guns and grenades a lot. Shotgun, dual 9mm pistol and her infamous Kalina Ann. Trish also becomes playable too, utlizing the Sparda sword, her guns, pandora and her own barehands infused with lightning. Trish in fact is very fast with her barehand moves and is very fun to play along with using sparda as an ability.

Level design for DMC4 is not half bad either. Sure platforming is still as bad thanks to the fixed camera but there is something even worse than that and it is my least favourite mission moment ever in DMC4, the board games. It's a board game essentially with a dice you can manipulate and roll to get to your objective. If you land on gold, you advance to purple and complete the objective. If you hit blue, you get spammed with red and green orbs and you collect as much as possible. If you land on red which is a lot of times, you fight enemies which can be completely random. This isn't as bad the first time you do it and sure you replay it as dante but Mission 19, you have to do it at least 5 times and more red appears so more enemies to fight and it goes in a circle till you hit a gold or purple spot. In addition, you refight the bosses again. Bosses arent half bad but lack any charisma and charm DMC3 bosses had. They are ok but not as memorable, except the one cutscene with dante and Agnus, the best moment in the game ever. 

Overall, DMC4 is a solid game and still worth picking up but ultimately has weaker story than DMC3. If you want to play for story, dont pick it up. If you want lots of gameplay and action, in addition to playing vergil, trish and lady, but this game.

121913067.review:
I recently streamed myself playing through all of the main Nero/Dante story of DMC4 and about half of Vergil mode so here's my thoughts:

First of all short answer to the question many may have, is this game good? Yes! I think if you enjoy other DMC games and other Hack and Slash like games then I think you will enjoy this. 

Now for the long version. 

I am a relatively new fan of the Devil May Cry series. I have played both 1 and 3 via the HD collection over the past summer. I am also really bad at games where I have to learn combos or remember button inputs for attacks. That being said the game is pretty easy to learn and was a really fun experience overall! I am not gonna really go into the story for this review to keep it relatively spoiler free even though the game is over 10 years old at this point. However, I think the story was fine. While I was not amazed by it, I found it entertaining which personally is all I want. I also often had a little trouble hearing what the characters were saying to the point where I had to have subtitles on (highly recommend). I am not sure if this is a known issue with this version of the game but could have just been me.

Some people may have an issue with the new protagonist, Nero. This may be due to how we just spent 3 whole games as Dante so they may feel it kind of questionable that we gotta play as this guy for like most of the game. I personally don't have much of an issue. I don't mind Nero, I prefer Dante like I assume many do but Nero is fine to me. Nero is very fun to play as and an excellent character to start off with because he is relatively simple to learn since he has only one main weapon being the Red Queen (motorcycle sword is honestly a really stupid yet badass weapon and yes I will take your entire stock). He also has two side weapons his gun, the Blue Queen, and his demon arm which is tool to grab and deal major damage to enemies and bosses with a unique animation for just about every enemy in the game. While I haven't played Lady and Trish mode yet the other playable characters are super fun to play as too but if you played the other DMC games you already know what to expect kind of for Dante and Vergil (more on Vergil later)! Due to how Nero feels to play and the game feeling super easy after the first boss it is kinda clear this game was meant to be an introduction game for new fans which is totally fine! However, one major gripe with the difficulty is the handicap mechanic. If you die to a boss then the game will automatically adjust the difficulty of the boss and lower your score. If the game simply asked "Do you want to make the boss easier?" before making it easier for you that would be fine but the game does not do that. I want to be able to play the game and learn from my previous death and then get better at fighting the boss rather than the game forcefully giving me a baby rattle cause I messed up. 

My biggest issue with the game is that it feels very unfinished at times. I personally think this is most apparent in the last section of the game where the plot just kinda stops and you can finally now play as Luig-I mean Dante. Dante is incredibly fun to play as and I love his arsenal in this game. However the game only lets you play as him for a few missions of the whole game and then that's it no more Dante. During the time you play as Dante you re-fight multiple bosses that you did as Nero. Now while I normally do not mind re-fighting bosses it is such a let down that during the time you play as Dante you are essentially just doing the same thing again, nothing new other than the levels to actually fight them which are just the same maps but with new objectives like portals you have to take to progress. Then you have to refight the same bosses AGAIN in mission 19 (but I can give this a pass since it is similar to the boss re-fights in 3). This makes the game feel noticeable unfinished like they ran out of time, ideas, or something to make new stuff for the last part of the game (I don't exactly know what happened but I have been told the game was not 100% finished). I would have much preferred the game had a separate mode for Dante and a separate mode for Nero or maybe a choice to play as whichever you want after completing their mode OR SOMETHING. Granted the Bloody Palace mode you can play any character you want so I guess there's always that. also whoever did that last dice level is my sworn enemy 

Quick thoughts on Vergil mode: It's fun cause I mean come on it's Vergil he's awesome. I really like the concept of the concentration meter but the execution is very weird. I get its supposed to be in character for Vergil's tactful personality but I dunno I think you gain way too little meter for actually attacking and you know playing the game and you gain way too much meter for standing around like an idiot. It is also feels a little too punishing if you even mess up even once. I know it may sound contradictory but it is also kinda OP. I have crushed nearly every single boss I fought with him with ease. I beat the first boss in what felt like seconds due to the sheer damage output of  having high meter and Judgment Cut End while super cool I don't really see a downside? I think the idea for the meter is genuinely really good but it needs a little more balancing in my opinion. I need to play a bit more to get more full thoughts on it, maybe I'll make a follow up review to this including my thoughts on Lady/Trish mode. I am also looking forward to playing Devil May Cry 5 which I have been told is really good!

Overall while I did have some issues with the later half its still a really fun game that is worth your time and money to play! I actually kind of prefer the gameplay in 4 over 3 personally but I think that may differ from person to person. I can totally see myself going back to the game to try and improve and get better style ratings and mission rankings!
Score: 7/10

This was my first ever real review other than the one sentence one for Yakuza Zero. I hope you enjoyed! (this was not supposed to be this long lol)

120602315.review:
Devil May Cry 4 is a good game. I would like to preface this wholw rant with that. DMC4 is good. However, it personally pisses me off. 

So, the story of DMC4 follows new character in the franchise Nero. He is a angru kid with anger issues that thinks he is way cooler than he actually is and I love him for it. He grew up in a city of Fortuna, that is controlled by a cult that worships demon Sparda as a god. One day a "mysterious" assassin attacks the church of this cult and kills it's pope leader. Nero is tasked with tracking down this "mysterious" attacker and apprehending him. What no one knows is that Nero has an ace up his sleeve, a demonic hand that gives him incredible power. The story of DMC4 is not as good as DMC3 was. While DMC3 was a family drama with characters having all sorts of trauma over their relatives, DMC4 is a love story with kind of flawed execution. Nero is very angry and angsty protagonist, but it works for this story overall, since him failing again and again to save the love of his life and then angrily punching the floor until it breaks is a powerful visual. But that's where some people might disagree, since seeing this kid's overdramatic reaction to everything might be annoying, especially seeing "too cool to care' attitude of a seocnd protagonist Dante, whose role of rival and a mentor for Nero kind of steals the spotlight. 

Being the first game on a new set of hardware since PS2, DMC4 has a huge jump in graphics over previous games, making probably themost betiful game in the series visually. Characters have this almost 3D anime design, the environments are bright and colorful, and enemies never looked this detailed in DMC before. Even compared to newer DMC5 I probably prefer the visuals here. 

But the main issue with DMC4 lies with it's gameplay. Overall, the game is pratically unfinished in a state that it's in. Half of the levels are repeats from the first half but with stupid annoying gimmicks on top. The enemy roster consists of annoying creatures that do not allow you to freely style on them, and the game really likes to overuse them. The bosses are frequently repeated two to three times and it probably has one of the worst bosses in the series on a level of a freaking "Infested Chopper" from DMC2. The levels always have some stupid time-wasting gimmick with them, and the game almost seems getting worse as you go futher until character switch in the middle of the game shakes things up.
As for the characters, Nero leaves a strong impression as a newcomer. You will be controlling him for the majority of the game, but his moveset is pretty limited. He has only one sword, one gun, and his powerful demon arm. Despite that, each of those have their own gimmicks associated. The sword "Red Queen" has a motorcycle revving mechanism attached to the handle, allowing to increase the power of attacks with it. The gun "Blue Rose", is giant double barreled revolver, that in it's base form is just another DMC gun, but really shines if you manage to get used to it's Charge Shot, that in it's highest level can do ridiculous amounts of damage. Nero's devil arm is what makes his whole kit work, it's a context sensitive "I win" button that is really satsfying to use and animations that you get as a result of a succesful attack, especially in Devil Trigger, are a blast to watch and very satsfying to land. on bosses it is a reward in itself for good gameplay, since the boss needs to get stunned first before you can buster them. And there are situations where your reaction and use of the arm can really make or break situation. it's more rewarding than any QTE.
Dante on the other hand. Well, he has three different melee weapons, three "guns", and access to five different styles. Trying to utilise all of them effectively is the real challenge with Dante and all of it combined make DMC4 Dante one of the most complex characters in action games. He doesn't have Nero's cool demon arm, but he makes up for it with amounts of style and swagger that is never seen. The guy knows that he is strongest thing alive and is not ashamed for it. 
The Special Edition of DMC4 also adds new characters, female demon hunters Trish and Lady, and fan-favorite motivational speaker, katana weilding, sword summoning Vergil. All of them have their own moves and skills, but the problem is, there is still no new content for them. It's either running Bloody Palace, or running over the old and tired levels with the same annoying enemies and stupid useless gimmicks and puzzles. 

Like I said, DMC4 is good, but it should have been much better than it is. It is already a tall order following up probably the best action game of all time, but the lack of actual content, annoying puzzles, and worst enemy roster since DMC2 really make this game almost kind of a letdown. i both love and hate coming back to this game. And th fact that it was followed up by one of the most tone-deaf, pandering and insulting reboots in history make everything feel worse, while we got actual good closure for franchise after 11 years of waiting.

Bien, tras haber por fin terminado el juego tras mucho tiempo, puedo decir que cambiaré radicalmente mi reseña anterior. Por cierto, para ser un juego del ¡2008! es impresionante. 

1) "El sistema de guardado es inexistente". Bueno, en este punto creo que si tengo razón. Es una cagada el sistema de guardado, a veces te morís y el punto de control es el principio de la misión. Muy malo.
2) "El combate es lento, se siente pesado y los enemigos son poco llamativos, variados o cuanto menos interesantes. Los combos se basan en apretar determinado botón en determinado orden, y  luego de haber jugado otros juegos de acción similares, este sistema me parece bastante simple y tosco, por no decir incómodo". En cuanto al combate, tengo que decir que es lo mejor del juego por diferencia. Si bien se siente algo torpe, no es ni de lejos malo. Los enemigos si son muy malos, los jefes también. Y los combos la verdad que son bastante llanos. 
3) "La historia no es nada entretenida, los personajes son todos iguales, adolescentes prepotentes que no tienen la mínima idea de nada más allá de dar volteretas..." Bueno ahora pienso diferente. Si bien la historia es mala, no es tan mala. Entretiene. Es verdad, el antagonista final es malísimo, pero bueno es DMC tampoco esperamos Lotr.
4) "La cámara es ciertamente insoportable. Creo que quisieron darle un aspecto cinemático, pero lo volvieron muy tedioso". De acuerdo con mi antiguo yo, es lo peor del juego, lejos.
5) "El menú y las opciones son horribles y poco intuitivas". Me parece increíble que a lo largo de los años hayan dejado ese sistema de entrar al menú para curarse, es muy raro ¿Y lo de las gemas para revivir?¿Qué significa eso?
6) "La banda sonora es siempre la misma y cansa muy rápido". Ciertamente es malísima.
8) "El diseño de nivel es realmente feo y poco entretenido de jugar". Efectivamente, son horribles.

Un aspecto muy negativo del juego es que tengas que repetir jefes con Dante, muy floja esa parte. A estas alturas es un 7/10 este juego, pero lo recomiendo para Pc malas ya que entretiene bastante. Por otro lado no me gusta nada que pese 24GB, es demasiado para lo que es este juego. Eso es todo.

120200910.review:
While the story isn't as engrossing as DMC 3's, DMC 4 still manages to be an insanely fun time with the writing just as nutty and comedic as ever if not more so. Playing as the new character Nero adds a fun level of depth to the usual standard Dante affair these games tend to offer. However you get to play as Dante through the later half of the game but essentially it's just a trek back from where Nero originally came including previously defeated bosses (of which you fight 4 of the 10 bosses repeatedly, very lame) which can make the 3rd act feel a bit like a slough to get through. On top of that you have some confusing level design choices which will leave you wondering around areas (Fortuna Castle & The Forest being the worst) muttering "where the fuck do I go?" as you cycle back through the same area multiple times. It's not bad, but it can be a bit frustrating sometimes. 

Combat and pacing are for the most part stylish and high octane with some neat, small additions to the arsenal (including Nero's own unique move set and weapons) that makes the game stand out from its' predecessors. Some moments spent solving environmental puzzles that are nothing more than reprieve from the combat sections scattered throughout the levels. All the while everything is in glorious HD 3D visuals courtesy of the 7th generation of consoles and while some of the textures can be low res in game, the character models and cutscenes look amazing with a rocking sound track to boot that gives us a sample of what we would later hear in 5. Good stuff.

Along with the rockin tunes, the game's tone and atmosphere is hilarious as ever and watching Dante monologue in a Shakespearean manner with a boss before fighting him is not only funny but why you come to play DMC games. Nero in contrast is a much more serious, brooding character but still has his charms and can be pretty cool himself at times which makes him not completely unlikable. He's unintentionally funny though so be prepared to cringe at some of his more "dramatic" moments. Dante is as he's always been which is irreverent, sarcastic, and wildly nonchalant about yet another impending doomsday scenario involving demons, destruction and calamitous peril. He never fails to not put a smile on your face. 

Overall, you're gonna love this experience if you've played through the previous titles and loved them. Having played through all 4 back to back and 5 upon its' release I can't say this is my favorite (that's a toss up between 3 and 5) but I can say this is still a DMC game at its' core and it's damn fun to play and really pretty to look at visually as well. Definitely worth a purchase, especially if on sale. Now go slay some demons! 

Oh, and  "KYRIEEEEEEEEE! *sobs* "

DMC3 set a high bar. And yet, this game fails to surpass it. DMC3 had great gameplay, enemies you had to plan out how to fight, brutal bosses, and was just overall fun. Overall, this game is terrible. I would highly suggest you just watch the story on YouTube and not play through this snore fest. Still better than DMC2.

To put it simply: the D-pad does NOT work with this game. This isn't an issue for Nero, but you can imagine how frustrated I was when 10 hours in the game switched me to Dante only to leave me stuck in trickster stance. I had to literally re-learn the entire game on keyboard so that I could actually use the other three styles, and furthermore if you're using the shift key for guns like me, rapid-firing Ebony & Ivory is near impossible. I have played TONS of games on steam with this controller and this is the first time I'm having any sort of issue with it. I even went back to some of my other games to make sure my D-pad wasn't just borked, and sure enough, it worked just fine. This game is FUN, I cannot stress that enough; but I can't help but feel that the rug was pulled out from under me due to some programming oversight.

119370878.review:
DmC 4 is a great game that follows the events of the original DmC trilogy, now with a new protagonist and a new story to follow, and even though it might not be perfect, it's definetly worth checking out both for gameplay and story purposes.

Yes, we have a new badass white haired demon hunter in the controls. This time, we follow Nero, a young man that is part of a religious order that worships Sparda, the demon that sealed the two worlds, betrayed his own kind, just to protect the humans. Sparda is also Dante and Vergil's dad as you might recall from previous games. Not to spoil much, but the events of the game kinda force Nero and Dante to cross paths which leads into Nero discovering a big conspiracy and seeing himself fighting against the people he fought side by side with while also trying to protect his loved ones.
I honestly think that Nero is a great character, he is young and impulsive and extremely emotional and his flaws are what make him great, at least for me. Also the fact that he has a demon arm that he can use to throw them around like Invincible throws bags of trash. 

About the gameplay, a lot changes. Not only do we get a new character with new mechanics but this Special Edition also gives us 4 more to play with. That's right, not only are Dante and Nero playable but also Lady, Trish and Vergil are a part of the roster too. Their gameplay differs a lot from eachother, making each character unique and fun. You will be playing as Nero most of the time, but his mechanics are very fun to compensate for the hours he steals from other characters. His sword can be revved up like a motorcycle, which gives it more power, and he can use his Devil Bringer arm to act as a grappler and grab demons around, with each demon having special animations for being grabbed. Dante is amazing here too and he shares the campaign with Nero, his gameplay is just crazy fun once you get the hang of it and his personality makes it all the better. Unfortunately, you only play as him for less than half of the game (about 4 hours) so you might be left wanting for more. Lady and Trish work the same, you play as Lady first and then Trish (which is a shame because I really like her gameplay here), with Lady doing justice to the name "The Walking Arsenal" by having her whole gameplay based around guns and charged attacks while Trish is a lot faster and more versatile while still being really fun and powerful.
Vergil is back from DmC 3, this time having a whole mechanic based around precision and concentrated gameplay. He has some really fun moves that he can use and he is overall just a really stylish character. Unfortunately, his gameplay is hindered by the game's enemy design. It really took a drop from the third installment and it could make you annoyed at times. Some enemies are just outright stupid for what they are, but if you are playing on Devil Hunter difficulty and just going through things normally, that shouldn't annoy you too much.
Overall, I think the gameplay really got better based on the previous games even if the enemy design didn't.

About the characters, I gotta say I enjoyed Nero. He is young and impulsive as I mentioned before and those flaws are what make him interesting. Dante is even more laid back than before, only ever going serious mode when shit demands it and it works amazingly. His interactions with other characters are really fun to watch, and the way he interacts with Nero really shows some growth, He is not just a kid anymore, he is wiser and older and with that comes some responsability. That isn't stopping him from being cool as fuck, though. Nothing is, really. The secondary characters, more specifically the ones from the cult are interesting and actually show some personality.

The soundtrack is again a banger, and while not as good as maybe DmC 3 or 5, it definetly deserves some praise. It's good and it's gonna get you pumped for battle.

Overall, this game improves a lot of stuff from DmC3, even if making some mistakes that the previous games didn't (at least not as much) but I think the new story is interesting, the gameplay is amazing and full of variety and Nero is a great character. His interactions with old timers like Dante and Trish fill me with excitment and the way he acts throughout the game's story is honestly quite relatable for me. Plus, everything sets the scene perfectly for the next installment, which is, in my opinion, one of the best games of all time: Devil May Cry 5.

119146157.review:
[b]The 4th DMC game, featuring Vergil from Devil May Cry 3.[/b]

It's a rushed-out Nero game with Dante forced in because they were supposedly afraid of angering Dante fans according to an open interview, so you end up just backtracking through Nero's path with Dante halfway through the game and fighting most of the same bosses again as soon as you get to use him.

Compared to DMC 3's extremely well-structured story, this game's plot feels like it's just there where the only interesting parts are the crazy Dante and Nero stuff.

Gameplay-wise, it's an overall improvement over 3, featuring better controls and general camera-work.
Both Nero and Dante play great, but originally being a Nero game, Dante feels out of place as there are loads of enemies that he fights that feel very awkward to deal with as him. Dante's also the hardest character out of everyone in this game to be stylish with due to his huge arsenal of movesets, though you don't have to worry too much about that if you're not trying to get too fancy with combos and such.
Difficulty-wise, this is probably the easiest DMC game since DMC 2, with only some uncommon enemies that are there to be more annoying than difficult. Most of the bosses are real slow and have extremely simple movesets too, even on the highest difficulty settings.

The new characters you can play as in SE are Trish, Lady, and Vergil. Just like in DMC 3: SE, you're only playing through the game's base missions as these characters. Story-wise, the only important cutscenes are Vergil's, but he only gets two, which are just him showing off his motivation & power, and making a couple of comments about the game's villains.
Trish plays similarly to Dante with some odd controls you'll have to get used to, but has fun traps you can set-up around the field.
Lady is probably the easiest to use as she's the slow-attacking, heavy-hitter type with some agility to boot. She can't do crazy combos like everyone else, but her charged attacks are extremely strong and versatile, which bring up her stylish ranks a lot easier than everyone else.
Vergil is perhaps the absolute strongest character in this game, and his power scales real hard with how good you are with him; a massive improvement over his DMC 3 counterpart. He's strong, agile, and can clear rooms full of demons instantly & constantly with efficient use of his Judgement Cut End.

As a product, the game's only real value is in the new characters that you can play with, and maybe that new difficulty mode where enemies are in huge abundance.
The Special Edition part mainly adds more to what was originally a rushed-out game as well as some gameplay tweaks, which are unnoticeable to people who play casually, but very much more-so for the worse for those who've gotten real good at the original, as some crazy techs and combos are either no longer possible here or have become really inconsistent.
As a PC port, it's not perfect. It features some general PC settings, but for example, you can't turn off the main things that cause common stuttering problems without editing the game's .exe file through a hex editor.
Most of the DLC is just for lazy losers who'd rather pay for rewards that are originally meant for people who actually play and get skilled at the game. Terrible practice, especially considering that you could unlock all bonus stuff via cheat-code inputs in the previous game.
If you're in it just for the base-game Dante & Nero stuff, you might be better off just getting the original non-Special-Edition version for cheap, though it may take a bit of tweaking to get that running; the Special Edition's graphics are barely an improvement anyway.

119010873.review:
I recommend this game under 2 conditions:

1. You recognize that the original released in 2008 and you are willing to deal with it being a little clunkier than the Steam release date makes it seem

2. You want to go play DMC 5.

Now, addressing the main issues of the game come down to the age of the game. This game is over a decade old and some things have changed with time. The controls are kind of clunky compared to modern games kind of like it, but the big issue is the camera. Sometimes you get 3rd person control, but it's generally for short moments. Otherwise, you get fixed camera angles, which throws off you movement direction until you get used to it and makes dodging and directional inputs kind of a pain at first. This is honestly my only real complaint.

On the other hand, the game is fun and easy enough to pick up, but if you want those SSS ranks, you're gonna have to get good at it. You feel yourself improving in ways I've really only seen in something like Sekiro, and it makes you feel like a badass. In addition, if you don't like the default controls, you can rebind them however you want.

The final thing of note is the story. Is it the greatest story ever told? No. Are you gonna go play DMC 5? If yes, you'll want this. Otherwise you'll just be like, "Who tf is Nero? What's with his arm? How did it become a sword? wtf?" Honestly, I'd recommend playing 3 and 4 before 5, but whatever. In addition, playing through this game will get you ready for 5 mechanically. Other than a few things, DMC 5 plays very much like a smoother, more refined 4. A lot of combos are still there with a lot more added. Being mediocre on this for you 1st playthrough will get you ready to get those S-SSS ranks in DMC 5.

Essentially, the game is good enough on it's own, but the following game makes this an easy recommendation just purely due to how it will affect your experience in the sequel.

118237638.review: Devil May Cry 4 keeps the action going with yet another solid installment in the DMC series. Starring Nero, a new protagonist who boasts a youthful brashness and a powerful *literal* Devil Arm, you'll go on yet another hack and slash adventure of combo-mastery and boss-fights. I did a singular playthrough of DMC 4 on normal (Devil Hunter) difficulty with Nero, and I had a pretty good time with it. Despite there being less Dante (he's still there for a little!), the game still kept its charm for the most part. Nero has some very satisfying gameplay with very fun-to-use combos. The game keeps its over-the-top nature throughout, though I would argue the sexualization of the women in this game was really pushed too far, to the point of ridiculousness (looking at you, "Gloria"). In terms of gameplay, I think my main con was that the boss diversity in this game is a little low. Because of how the story is told, you end up fighting the few bosses you encounter several times over and over, and while some change slightly with each instance, others are literally carbon copies of themselves from earlier in the game, which I would imagine gets a little boring on repeat playthroughs. This was one of my primary reasons for not replaying the game on higher difficulties or with other characters (I also started DMC 5 shortly after finishing DMC 4 and holy shit that game is so good I don't know why I'd ever go back). Overall, DMC 4 is pretty solid, and while it's definitely the weakest of DMC 3/4/5, I'd still play it if you're gonna play those three games, but maybe wait for a small sale.

This is one of those games that was rushed but still managed to be a masterpiece. Even masterpieces can have flaws but i feel like the gameplay and the in depth combat really brings it up to be a masterpiece. The game is challenging and encourages you to get better at the game cuz it's so fun to pull of those combos. There is no other game that has combat this smooth and stylish without the game trying to cry about it.

Gameplay 9.5/10 - Some camera issues here and there but nothing too fancy when it comes to negatives.
Combat 11/10 - Nothing to really say about this cuz it hardly can get any better than this.
Story 7.5/10 - is good up until you reach the Dante part which is also kinda cool i guess. Cuz it's just Dante being a badass as he always is, Trying to clean up the mess Nero made.
Graphics: Really good for it's time and the art is amazing to look at

As far negatives go:
Boss fights are not that good except for a couple stand out ones like Credo which is an insane fight.
Bosses get repeated too much especially by the end of the game.
Some mobs are made around Nero's combat and not the other characters.
A couple achievements are a bit too challenging if you are an achievement hunter, They can be done with an insane amount of practice or you cheese them if there is a cheese for the achievement you wanna go for

Final rating: 9/10 - It could definitely be a 10/10 if the bosses weren't repeated too much / Bosses were better designed and i think the game is slightly too long which makes getting S ranks for missions a bit too dragged if you go for those achievements

116431917.review:
This game has been a blast <3
The story is a bit weaker than 3's, but it's still pretty okay with some genuine good moments here and there... and some beautiful, hilarious moments thanks to Dante - shoutouts to Mission 17 in particular!

However, the real shine of DMC4 is just how GOOD combat feels! It was already prety great in 3, but I loooooved just playing the game and executing combos in this one! Most of the bosses were fun (definitely more consistent than those in 3) though none are *quite* as good as the best fights in 3. However, Nero, the newcomer, is a blast to play as - he's pretty similar to Dante, but the things that make him unique are just pure ADRENALINE, and exploiting his moveset is just, SO SATISFYING!
Though it is not the game's biggest strength, I think it looks pretty good for the time, too ^^
Thanks to all this - and some good mission setpieces besides the Lost Woods - the whole ride is just pure, cheesy, satisfyinf fun, and makes DMC4 a delicious action game!

116419872.review:
La jugabilidad es buena, tienes a disposición 5 personajes, siendo el devil may cry con mas personajes jugables hasta la fecha, todos con mecánicas divertidas y bastante variadas con sus combos, armas y habilidades propias, las cuales vas desbloqueando con puntos que consigues jugando.

Con respecto a la dificultad, la veo equilibrada, a pesar de que la mayoría de enemigos a los que tenemos que derrotar son muy molestos, ya sea porque vuelan, se escondan bajo tierra, porten escudos o alguna especie de inmunidad a ciertos tipos de armas (sobre todo en dificultades altas), el juego te brinda las herramientas para poder derrotarlos, sin perder el estilo que caracteriza a la saga.

La banda sonora también muy buena, el problema es todo lo demás, la historia es mala y aburrida, los antagonistas son totalmente olvidables, sosos, genéricos y sin una pizca de encanto, excepto por algunas zonas, el diseño de los niveles son horribles, con mapas confusos, te pierdes en un bosque laberinto donde hasta usando guía da dolor de cabeza, ademas hay que repetirlos, ya que en la mitad del juego tienes que volver por donde viniste (solo que con otro personaje), enfrentándote a una versión mejorada de los mismos jefes que ya venciste, lo cual se hace MUY pesado, esto sumando a que esta saga apuesta a la rejugabilidad, pasándote varias veces el juego ya sea en modos mas difíciles o para mejorar la nota por puntuación, haciendo que el problema de repetitividad de mapas y diseño de niveles se multiplique por mucho.

Recomiendo el juego mas que nada por el palacio sangriento, un modo donde te ponen en una plataforma circular y tienes que sobrevivir a oleadas de enemigos que vienen cada vez mas fuertes, esto sumado a su gran jugabilidad, al numero de personajes jugables y su variedad de armas, hace que te olvides tanto de su pésima historia, como diseños de niveles y te centres mas en el hack and slash, usando combos complejos a fin de conseguir muchos puntos de estilo y mejorando tus mecánicas como jugador de este gran genero.
