116110557.review:
One full year after reviewing and finishing the HD collection of the first three installments in this franchise, I finally completed Devil May Cry 4. This has been a monumental and brutal journey in not just my quest for getting all the achievements in every Devil May Cry game, but for completing all the games I own at large. (skip to the last paragraph for my rating of the game and closing thoughts)

This game leaves a wonderful impression on the player in its opening sequence and the first few missions. The graphics are a massive step up from the previous installment, Devil May Cry 3; the environments are very diverse and gorgeous to look at and explore, the cinematography and direction of the cutscenes are both exciting and engaging, and the voice acting and animation (general presentation) are the best the franchise had seen up to this point.

For the first half or so of the game, you play as Nero: an entirely new devil hunter and the main character of this story. He’s reminiscent of young Dante from DMC 3 in terms of appearance, but he tends to be more emotionally expressive and prone to anger, making him more vulnerable and readable. The name of the game here is still being stylish and flashy, but this added layer of personality that Nero boasts makes him an even more transparent character than Dante, which helps with getting us to identify with his emotions and motives, thus making for a much more engaging experience overall.

During the first 11 missions of this game, you practically get to experience all of the environments and significant boss battles this game has to offer. The boss battles overall are about as good as they were in DMC 3. Nero’s signature move, the Devil Buster, has different effects based on which boss you’re fighting and the state they’re in. The first boss for example, Berial, has three separate states: his normal state, his weakened state, and his stunned state. He progressively transitions from his normal state to his stunned state as he takes more damage. In his normal state, Berial is immune to getting grabbed by your Devil Buster; however, as you keep hitting him, he’ll lose his flames and go into his weakened state, which opens him up for a grab animation. Keep hitting him and he’ll transition to his stunned state, leaving him open for you to deal more damage via your combo attacks and/or another grab move (the grab move here would be a different animation given that Berial is now stunned, not just weakened). Most boss battles have similar mechanics to Berial with minor alterations, which makes them compelling to replay and dissect.

After the first 11 missions are done, you stop playing as Nero and switch into playing as Dante, and that’s where most of the issues I had with this game start to rear their ugly heads. Dante, in my opinion, feels like a shell of his former self in the gameplay department. His arsenal of weapons is drastically reduced from DMC 3 and a lot of style-specific elements from DMC 3 (like his ability to run up walls using Trickster) were abandoned. However, the single coolest addition to Dante’s moveset is the ability to change styles using the D-Pad. Changing styles is now no longer the arduous commitment and pace-killer it was in DMC3, you can now change between styles freely while fighting. This really helps cover up Dante’s reduced weapon variety by allowing the player to switch up the style of gameplay on the fly, essentially maximizing the freedom and creativity afforded to the player with the current selection of weapons, regardless of how small it may be.

Unfortunately, my gripes with Dante’s section aren’t limited to his gameplay; the worst aspect of his section are the missions he goes through. Backtracking in DMC is nothing groundbreaking or new; however, it has never been as blatant and offensive as it is here. In Dante's section, you have to go through all the environments that you went through as Nero, fight the same types of enemies, and take down the same bosses again.

Again, fighting the same boss battles and backtracking is nothing new in DMC, but even the first DMC did this way better. In that game, every time you fought the same boss battle for the second and/or third time, the environment was different and the mechanics of the boss fight were altered. I’m not just talking about giving the boss a bit more health or making them hit harder or more frequently, I’m talking straight up giving them *new* moves, changing up their pattern of attacking, and giving them new strengths and weaknesses – all of which allow for a familiar yet distinct experience that makes it feel like the boss evolved and grew stronger in tandem with your growth and evolution as a player. This couldn’t be farther from the case in this game. When you fight these boss battles again as Dante, you’re fighting the EXACT same bosses you fought as Nero. Same environments, same strengths and weaknesses, and same attack patterns. The only difference is you get to fight them as Dante this time.

Eventually, you move on to mission 19, which is one of the worst DMC missions I’ve ever experienced. Mission 19 is a boss rush mission; you go through 5 unique floors with each floor taking you to a different zone. This mission is utterly lazy garbage. You fight the same boss battles you JUST beat as Dante just a couple missions ago, which already were entirely recycled bosses you previously beat as Nero, AGAIN. To make matters worse, they’re once again the same environments, same strengths and weaknesses, and same attack patterns; all recycled for the 3RD TIME in the same playthrough. This was utterly baffling to me when I first played it, and going through the game more than 7 unique times to get various achievements only hammered home how lazy and redundant the repetition of these fights were.

This is why it took me so long to finish the achievements for this game; this game’s structure isn’t fun to replay at all. This game does have the highest amount of playable characters in any DMC game, thanks to the fact that the Special Edition brings over 3 totally unique and fun characters in Vergil, Trish and Lady. This also really helps with getting through the redundancy of the game and its missions.

When I first started playing this game last year, it was a few days after I had beaten DMC 3 completely, which was one of my favorite gaming experiences of 2021. The first 11 missions of this game were breathtaking, and it made me very optimistic for the journey I was about to experience. However, everything following mission 11 really soured the overall experience and made me grow to hate this game. The achievements went from being a thrilling challenge to an unbearable chore, and I had to put this game away for months because of it.

After taking a break and then coming back and learning the new characters with their immensely unique gameplay styles, my desire to finish this game was rejuvenated and I somehow sat down for 40 hours over the span of a week and finished the remaining achievements.

I think this game benefits a lot from having a desire to learn and improve. If you’re in it just to beat a set of achievements, this game will bore you to death and it will be intolerable. If you play through this game just once, I believe the issues I brought up would still be a hindrance to your enjoyment, but it won’t be nearly as bad as what I had to experience due to my plethora of playthroughs. Overall, this game is good and has a lot of gameplay diversity through its many characters and their respective unique gameplay styles, but the game’s overall bad aspects really drag it down.

Overall, I give it a 7/10. It’s a good time as long as you stay away from achievement hunting. I also recommend you try out all of the characters at least once; it is truly tragic that superb characters like Lady and Trish can only be experienced through the poor missions of this game, but their movesets make the experience fun regardless.

Right so i've been binging this series and so far I have very much enjoyed my time with it.
- DmC 1 I enjoyed and my god what an incredible game for 2001
- DmC 2 I actually enjoyed to some extent because it was short and kinda cool ngl, though Dante was mega edgelord and the game was mad repetitive
- DmC 3... I'm sure you know how much of a masterpiece that game is so 10/10
and i've just finished up this game and I've got a a bit to say about it

So to start off this game is fucking gorgeous for 2008, idk if they touched up the graphics in the special edition but man this game is colorful and pretty.
So this game probably has my favorite combat so far, I LOVE Nero's combat, his combos are fucking awesome looking and feel great to pull off. Nero has so much new shit and I am all for it, sure he has some stuff Dante had but I feel it is needed for the combos.
Dante is also a fucking blast to play as he can now style switch mid fight and it is amazing. He feels great once you get back into the groove of the Dante playstyle and man you can do some sick shit with his new weapons. 

I'll try to keep this spoiler free
Now the story is alright in this, I kinda got lost in what was happening from the beginning but that is to be expected from this series for me. I wish they touched up on how Nero met Kyrie and how Nero got all of his shit but maybe in the next game they will. The villians are...kinda shit ngl. and the final fight is horrible... but pretty sick
Dante's personality really shines in the final acts and god damn I love em, he is so fucking cool.
I fucking loved Nero, I felt he was a very relatable character for the situation he is in while also being a mega badass.

Now for the bad
This game gets super fucking repetitive... Literally the second half of the game is you just retracing your steps and re-fighting all the previous bosses. The game also includes Trish, Lady, and Virgil as playable characters but there is no point as you just get to play through the story again but as different characters, no new cutscenes besides their starting cutscenes (there could be more but i couldn't be fucked playing through it again to see).

115322398.review:
I'm late to the party on this title but I'm having a blast! Playing this for the 1st time in 2022 the game shows its age graphics-wise but the gameplay itself is solid and audio is top notch hardcore action rock. 

Minor gripes so far are that Nero's jumps are short and fast (think Fox/Falco in Smash) and that fixed camera angles can lead to reversed inputs on entering new areas (Resident Evil roots raising their heads).

For those who have never played a character action game from either Capcom or Platinum there is a steep learning curve. Be prepared to learn how to move and combo with your character for the first hour or so before advancing the game. When you feel like you've hit a wall you'll probably need to improve your skills so watch a combo vid or tutorial on YouTube to see what you've been missing out on. This will take practice, practice and some more practice.

I'm on Mission 4 now and am doing OK. Unlocking moves is the priority as well as enjoying the over the top action and cut scenes as the story progresses.

115070147.review:
TL;DR: If you like solid games with really good combat mechanics, throw your money at this.

For me, DMC4:SE sits on the line of almost being an S-Tier videogame. The story is just not my kinda thing, but the gameplay is 150% solid and more than makes up for it. If you decide you do enjoy the game, you can extend the hell out of your mileage with the cheap Unlock All Modes DLC for some real challenges, and you can look up the ridiculous amount of special techniques people have found or 'created' to see just how high you can push your skill ceiling with each playable character.

__________________________________________________

I've had DMC4:SE on other platforms and played it significantly more on those. It's got fantastic gameplay, a silly story, 'teenager-cool' characters, and it's the first game that comes to my mind when someone says "Character Action", aside from maybe ULTRAKILL (which itself is greatly inspired by DMC).

There's only two criticisms I can really make about DMC4, and one of them is just personal taste:

Your mileage may vary on the story. It's silly campy schlock, which is a tone I've only ever enjoyed in a handful of games (Destroy All Humans and Duke Nukem 3D come to mind). Thankfully you can skip all of it and still enjoy the fantastic gameplay perfectly fine.

The other criticism is the DLC situation. One DLC to unlock all of Special Edition's extra gameplay modes is pretty necessary, thankfully [b]very[/b] cheap but still scummy. There's also a bunch of what I call "Pay to play less" DLCs, where you pay a premium for a kickstart in resources - a move that hurts the experience in my opinion, damaging the curve of unlocking things and getting to grips with each new unlock, naturally and smoothly getting better at the game over time.


DMC4:SE is still a fantastic game over a decade later, definitely worth the time of anyone who likes the Character Action genre (considering the DMC series codified the genre), likes a good challenge, and wants a smooth and visually striking experience with cathartic melee combat at its core.

114368685.review:
This is one of the weaker DMC games, but it's still a good time if you just want to kill some demons and relax. The main problem, as countless others have already said, is that it's really only half a game. DMC4SE adds lots of extra content, but the actual enemies and maps are still very lacking. 

Combat is arguably the deepest the series has been in terms of combo freedom, if you're into that kind of thing. That said, Dante only has three melee weapons and three firearms, and Nero's gameplay (while satisfying) is very simple. As far as the added characters, Trish and especially Lady are kind of bland to play. Vergil is the real winner in my opinion and an absolute blast.

Overall, definitely play this if you're a DMC fan or like stylish action games, but just don't expect a "complete" experience.

113617672.review:
"...And a voice echoed, Power, Give me more power! And if I become a demon, so be it, I'll endure the exile." <----- Most hype moment in any game :DDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDD

DMC 5 was about Vergil's rebirth and DMC 4 is about Nero's. There are some Jungian references in the early portion of the game (as boring and painful as the map/levels can be). Essentially, this is Nero's path of individuation as the hero and savior in the franchise (to accept both the good and evil within his soul/psyche; "The Marriage of Heaven and Hell" by William Blake). There are a lot of references to classical literature that the whole theme of the game is built off from (Both in DMC 4 and 5). I never would've imagined the series would be so deep after looking at how chaotic and silly it can be. 

Irritating to get used to at the start and there a lot of moments in the game where you're just suffering because you don't know what to do. Like a lot of trail-and-error which kind of kills this particular game's mood.

Still just as badass as DMC 5 if not more imo. But the characters are a lot more lovable in DMC 5 except Dante. Another series that identifies with everything I love about life and this world. Reading as much as you can makes everything surprising even videos games so much more enjoyable.

Long live Capcom!

112300655.review:
Devil May Cry is one of the best character action games made to date. 

The combat is really fluid and responsive especially with the high framerate options offered. Base DMC 4 let's you play through the game with the first half being Nero's campaign while the 2nd half is Dante's. Nero only has a small moveset but compensates with having the buster move which is a dedicated grab button. He was made with new players in mind as an introduction to the series. The exceed system also differentiates new and expert players. Expert players will have no problem hitting EX-Act at the right moment and basically maintaining Red Queen's gauge. On the other hand we have Dante, the main star of the DMC games. His kit is complex and hard to get used to. Style switching on the fly is a new mechanic in DMC4 that allows Dante to have 4 different functions on the Circle/B button. His new styles feel a bit weaker than they did in 3 but that was probably done to compensate with having style switching. Dante can also switch between 3 guns and 3 melee weapons making him really versatile. With that said, combat is also where the games suffers its flaws. The enemies really feel like they were designed for Nero which makes fighting these same enemies with Dante a bit tedious. The other problem with the game is that there aren't really a lot of areas. Dante's campaign is just Nero's but going through the stages backwards. 

 Dante feels really weird to play here but this is probably his most advanced iteration yet even with DMC5. There's just a lot to learn with the techniques in this game which drastically affects gameplay. Personally I still have not gotten used to Dante's DMC4 combat style. It's really fun to see his full potential when watching players like donguri. 

Special Edition adds Vergil, Trish and Lady. I haven't tried the other two but I can speak for Vergil. He is the most fun character to play in this game, I dare say he is also the most broken. Vergil's damage is just insane not to mention his heavy rain sword stun mechanic. He can also cancel any move he does with his trick teleport. His combat is just stylish, clean, and elegant. I advise you to beat the game ASAP just to get to play him in Bloody Palace. You won't regret playing as him.

DMC4 is a great game with a few flaws that if you can overlook, will guarantee that you'll have a great time.

112157652.review:
My review after finishing the game on the Normal Difficulty (Demon Hunter) 
Superb action game, made for all the creative combo makers and style enthusiasts!

Pros : 
-The game is fully playable and enjoyable with Keyboard only, the default layout is really good but you can customize the buttons as you wish (no double mapping offered in-game)

-Nero is a very fun character to learn the game with; he has a low barrier of entry but a high skill ceilling. 

-Dante is completely cracked; you will feel overwhelmed by his huge tool-box and at a low-level he will feel a lot weaker than Nero. This character has limitless potential; if it takes 100 hours to master Nero, it will take you 2000h to master Dante (if there even is such a thing...)

-Gameplay is top notch : precise, fast, flexible, creative, challenging and motivates you to keep playing and slowly mastering the mechanics. 

Cons : 
Started with the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller and the game had a hard time with the analogue stick threshold to switch from "Walk" to "Run". I had to push the stick against the rim with a lot of pressure to get it to register a "Run". I quickly understood I wouldn't be able to enjoy the game fully with my controller because of that problem, so I switched to Keyboard. No other games gave me this issue yet, be warned.

Verdict : If you're looking for a fun 20h single player action game, DMC4SE will satisfy you. If you're looking for a game with replayability, you can experience the story and the Bloody Palace (arcade mode/boss rush) with 3 characters (Trish, Lady & Virgil) other than the main two (Nero & Dante). I'd see myself easily playing for over 50 hours just trying them out and possibly +200h if I'm still as excited learning them to express my creativity in style!

111628582.review:
Ingredients
For the base

    300g strong bread flour
    1 tsp instant yeast (from a sachet or a tub)
    1 tsp salt
    1 tbsp olive oil, plus extra for drizzling

For the tomato sauce

    100ml passata
    handful fresh basil or 1 tsp dried
    1 garlic clove, crushed

For the topping

    125g ball mozzarella, sliced
    handful grated or shaved parmesan (or vegetarian alternative)
    handful of cherry tomatoes, halved 

To finish

    handful of basil leaves (optional)

Method

    STEP 1

    Make the base: Put the flour into a large bowl, then stir in the yeast and salt. Make a well, pour in 200ml warm water and the olive oil and bring together with a wooden spoon until you have a soft, fairly wet dough. Turn onto a lightly floured surface and knead for 5 mins until smooth. Cover with a tea towel and set aside. You can leave the dough to rise if you like, but it’s not essential for a thin crust.
    STEP 2

    Make the sauce: Mix the passata, basil and crushed garlic together, then season to taste. Leave to stand at room temperature while you get on with shaping the base.
    STEP 3

    Roll out the dough: if you’ve let the dough rise, give it a quick knead, then split into two balls. On a floured surface, roll out the dough into large rounds, about 25cm across, using a rolling pin. The dough needs to be very thin as it will rise in the oven. Lift the rounds onto two floured baking sheets.
    STEP 4

    Top and bake: heat the oven to 240C/220C fan/gas 8. Put another baking sheet or an upturned baking tray in the oven on the top shelf. Smooth sauce over bases with the back of a spoon. Scatter with cheese and tomatoes, drizzle with olive oil and season. Put one pizza, still on its baking sheet, on top of the preheated sheet or tray. Bake for 8-10 mins until crisp. Serve with a little more olive oil, and basil leaves if using. Repeat step for remaining pizza.

110504651.review: My experience with DMC4 was overall positive, but I think this game misses the mark in a lot of areas. I'd argue the combat system is done better than DMC3, but the enemies don't mix with some of the characters, specifically Dante. It feels like Nero was made to be the sole protagonist, and they slapped Dante in halfway through because what's a DMC game without Dante? My biggest gripe with DMC4 however are the missions themselves. This game is by far the worst when it comes to level gimmicks and puzzles, which were present in DMC1 and 3 but were handled much better in those games. The sole culprit as to why these levels leave a sour taste in my mouth is because they are meant to pad out game time. DMC4 is notorious for being rushed and unfortunately it feels like an unfinished product. I wish the special edition did more for this game than add new playable characters. I think this game leans towards a 7.5/10, which may seem harsh to some, but if I'm ever going back to this game, it's probably with the Bloody Palace mode because the main campaign was not a fulfilling experience.

110499809.review: 感觉sp版本的还算有良心啊，除了多加几个人物之外，主线剧情里面返程的路上好像也换成了丁叔？而且还加了点其他怪？这次重新打dmc4才发现很多之前没有注意的细节，比如整体的技能和小怪在什么时间节点出，不同的角色都可以用什么方式解决，大部分时候都是有最优解的，所以当你按照设计人员的设计思路打的时候就会很舒服，即便是我这种手残党也不会被卡在某个节点了，这种比后面的非官方的DMC要好很多，所以整体玩下来就会觉得很流畅，而不至于因为卡在某些节点而忽略了整个游戏的剧情和节奏。boss也有类似的感觉，巨大无比的boss和渺小的主角之间形成鲜明的对比，因此打的时候会出现很强烈的冲击感，打完也会有种别样的成就感，并且只要按照设计思路来打boss，基本上也能比较顺利的继续剧情，而不会出现卡在某个地方感觉很难受。再一个就是倒数第二关重新打boss的设计也可谓是神来之笔，重新打一遍boss相当于在你升级完了各种能力之后，重新体验之前的任务，会让你有种对比成长的感觉。现在回过头来看dmc4真的是一代经典啊，特别是对比了后面几代，以及某个网游的版本之后。

108123951.review:
Devil May Cry 4 ha sido un juego al que me ha costado acostumbrarme, bien porque tuve el error de jugarlo después de Devil May Cry Reboot, bien porque empiezas con un personaje más lento cuando en el 3 empezamos con Dante siendo un personaje ágil, o bien por otra cosa. No lo sé. 

Quiero empezar esta reseña hablando de una de las mayores características de este juego: tiene diferentes campañas con personajes mezclados: tienes la historia con Nero, un personaje totalmente nuevo introducido a la saga en este juego, más Dante (es decir, empiezas como Nero pero al llegar a x misión debes seguir como Dante); tienes la campaña con Lady y Trish, y la de Vergil (estas dos últimas no las he jugado). El cambio de personaje quizás pueda parecer duro, yo lo pensaba en un principio, pero nos encontramos con un factor decisivo: Nero tiene muchos combos y es el personaje principal en el que los desarrolladores han querido dejar el mayor peso, mientras que el Dante que nos presentan aquí es como el que tenemos en el 3 con su Rebellion, pero no tenemos tantos combos al no disponer de todo el arsenal que teníamos en el anterior juego numerado, pero se le añade el factor de que puede cambiar de estilos en mitad del combate que cambiará el efecto del botón B o Círculo más añadir ciertos combos al personaje (los cuatro estilos que desarrollamos en el DMC 3, siendo Trickster el estilo ágil; Swordmaster el estilo que nos permite hacer combos en el aire y lanzar ondas de choque de la espada; Gunslinger el estilo centrado en armas de fuego; y Royalguard es el estilo para aquellos que gusten de bloquear y contraatacar). En otras palabras, este Dante tiene menos combos pero sigue  siendo ágil y reparte bien. Algo que debo comentar es que he notado apresurada la ruta de Dante: si bien empiezas con Nero y él tiene armas fijas, Dante sigue ganando nuevas armas al derrotar a jefes, pero su parte es tan corta y las mejoras de las mismas son tan pocas que siento lo anterior mencionado, no es un Dante tan completo como el que vimos en la entrega anterior.

Hay algo novedoso en la tienda, y es que en este juego tenemos dos monedas: las típicas gemas rojas que gastamos en la tienda para los objetos y los cristales de vida y de Devil Trigger; y por otro lado las gemas valientes (no recuerdo si se llamaban así o de otra forma) que te dan al acabar cada misión o bien si te tienes que retirar y tienes que abandonar, momento en el que te dan varias gemas dependiendo de cuánto hayas avanzado o combatido. Estas gemas son las que se usan para mejorar y aprender habilidades pasivas y de las armas. 

Se habla mucho de cierta polémica, y es la de que [spoiler] la parte del juego de Dante es el camino que ha hecho Nero pero al revés. De igual forma, los jefes a los que se enfrenta Dante en dicho recorrido son los mismos a los que se enfrentó Nero. [/spoiler] Pienso que esto se puede haber hecho para amenizar el cambio de personaje, ya que estar acostumbrado a un personaje y que de pronto te hagan usar a otro distinto puede ser confuso, pero si has jugado al 3 la memoria muscular te puede ayudar, a mí me pasó. No obstante, opino que esto fue un tanto vago, además de [spoiler] reciclar jefes en la ruta de Dante, lo cual no dice mucha cosa buena ya que DMC siempre se ha destacado por tener muchos jefes distintos. [/spoiler]

Habiendo solo jugado a la historia de Nero/Dante, puedo decir que el juego está chulo. Al ser otro DMC no hace falta que haga varios párrafos detallándolo todo porque usa la misma estructura que los anteriores juegos. Hay algún villano memorable que me hizo mucha gracia, y Nero me parece un personaje soso en cuanto a personalidad. No nos dice mucho de él y tampoco suelta muchos comentarios. En definitiva, aunque fue un juego que me costó empezar por varios motivos y también porque Nero no es tan ágil como Dante al principio, puedo afirmar que los jefes me gustaron y es un juego divertido si te acostumbras. Pese a ello, siento que el 3 tenía más juego en cuanto a los combos. Recomiendo este juego para los que quieran seguir la evolución (o quizás progreso) de la saga.

107818417.review:
Devil May Cry 4... to be honest, my experience with it was kinda complicated. As someone who (at the point of this review) has only played DMC5 and just finished their first run in DMC4, this was kind of a rough task. Even though I've played Devil may cry 5 in every difficulty up to SoS and through the first half of DmD, I had my few struggles with this game. 
To be fair it was mostly mission 3 with it's puzzle aspect, as well as the other puzzle missions which I didnt really enjoy, paired with some boss fights which were a big pain. 
BUT in the end I do not regret buying it. Cutscenes and Combat themes mostly made me think this way. I'm really glad we got to see such precious cutscenes and they often lived up to my expectations concerning the game. The music fullfills it's job and even a friend of mine ,who just briefly watched me play through the endgame ,commented on the good sound of Nero's battletheme. 
I'm looking forward to playing the game as the other characters too, but I cant yet say anything about their routes.

So, a small summary of my review and some extra points: 
Pro:
- GREAT MUSIC 
- good dmc style combat (but you would need to watch out for some habits if you played dmc5 first, mostly Nero's combat)
- great cutscenes
- a mostly interesting story
- loveable, as well as hateable characters
- lovely voice acting
- a good amount of a challenge in general

Con:
- a weird way of pathing the missions in my opinion [spoiler] at least for the part where you switch to dante in the middle half and basically have to replay it all backwards [/spoiler]
- I did not like most of the boss fights and how they were designed
- enemies like faults and blitzes are just pure pain - truly hell's suffering if you dont watch out
- can tilt you really easy sometimes
- THERE IS RNG IN SOME LEVELS, which really got on my nerves. [spoiler] The whole dice rolling aspect in mission 19 just made the end a bit more painful than it could and should have been in my opinion [/spoiler]

But all in all: a worthy experience. I do not regret buying it

Capcom zrobiło świetną robote w remaku gry która zapadła mi w pamięć jako geniusz i arcydzieło. Oczywiście gra różni się od originału niestety raz lepiej a raz gorzej.

Najważniejszą cechą różniącą Remake od Originału jest trudność gry. Okej nie hejtujcie mnie mówiąc że pewnie grałem na Wspomaganym a nie na Hardcorze i że nie znam się ale grając na Standardowym nie czułem tego samego co w originale. Itemki leczące są praktycznie wszędzie i kiedy grałem pierwszy raz zginąłem tylko 1 od Bossa który jak cie złapie to po tobie (bez spoilerów widzicie jaki miły :P). Co prawda wrogom trzeba wpakować czasami 6 kul w morde żeby padli ale to i tak nie to samo uczucie jakie było w originale gdzie zombiaku mogły przyjąć o wiele wincej ammo i dopiero padnąć. Jest jeszcze sprawa jakże znanego Pana X który w Originale działał o wiele ciekawiej niż ten nam znany. Chodzi mi to najbardziej o to że nie gonił nas przez cały posterunek a potem lab (warto też wspomieć o tym że pojawiał się w jednym scenariuszu) tylko pojawiał się w wyznaczonych miejscach i po jego pokonaniu padał na ziemie i można była zebrać po nim loot (w postaci ammunicji) warto też powiedzieć coś o Super Tyrantcie który do gry został wpakowany na siłe. Skoro poruszyłem temat scenariuszy warto powiedzieć jak Capcom zwaliło cały sens Scenariusza A i Scenariusza B. Dla tych którzy nie kumają tematu kiedy pierwszy raz odpaliliśmy grę mogliśmy albo pójść Leonem Scenariusz A albo Claire Scenariusz B i te dwa scenariusze naprawdę się różniły a gdy przeszliśmy Claire albo Leonem to mogliśmy Leon B i Claire A a w Remake dostajemy jakiś 2nd Run który zmienia 1% gry. Nie podoba mi się też różnica broni, w originale bronie były troche ciekawsze np była kusza, SMG dla obu postaci albo chociaż brak tego słabego rewolweru dla Claire (chodzi mi o jej podstawowy).

Dobra koniec z rzeczami złymi przejdźmy do rzeczy które mi się podobają. Uwielbam rozwinięcie osobowości Marvin który w Originale pojawia się raz na początku gdy wchodzimy do RPD i odrazu nas wyrzuca z pokoju dając nam tylko karte i drugi raz już jako zombie gdy wchodzimy do tego pokoju innymi drzwiami. Kocham ale to Kocham Roberta Kendo w tej grze (ten koleś ze sklepu z bronią), tak jak w Originale ginął on odrazu na początku tak tutaj nie dość że ma ciekawsze linie to jeszcze jest dodatkowy tryb z nim jak ucieka aaaaa jak ja to kocham. Capcom zrobiło też genialną robote z Darmowym DLC "Ghost Survivor" zdecydowanie moim ulubionym jest "Bez Wyjścia" czy jakoś tak, tryby te są sprawdzianem dla graczy czy umią poradzić sobie z hordami zombie będąc słabo uzbrojony, ogółem musisz unikać zombiaki bo nie masz wystarczająca amma by je pozabijać i uciec do wyznaczonego miejsca nie jest to łatwe zadanie ale napewno jest fajne. 106764927.review:
Devil May Cry 4 is a repetitive game about walking to where you need to go as you tread areas that are unexplained and have no real purpose other than to get you to where you need to be. Due to this the game feels as really repetitive and boring cutscenes have no real value other than to help you doze off to sleep. Later in the game you see a bunch of really good cutscenes that remind me of DMC3 feels like a ray of light showing you a better more compelling story and interesting characters. 

The combat in this game is really good it's one of the reasons that kept me playing till the end with the carboard cutout main character and his poorly written and hard to connect to motivations. Combat is on the surface not complex and quite frankly appears if there's not a lot to work with, but there is there's a lot to work with and it's fun discovering and figuring that out especially when you get later in the game when it seems like it starts getting good. 

The bosses in the game are fine, I guess they're really easy and you roll over them most of the time. there's a part near the middle of the game that (not spoiling) you have to go somewhere, but this was probably the most lazy padding I've ever seen in a game you spend all the rest of the missions doing things you've already done only in reverse with silly gimmicks that barely change anything

Overall the game is good if you like pulling off cool combos and looking cool while doing it. I just didn't feel like putting more hours into the game because of how after the end I didn't feel like playing anymore due to knowing that the other 2 playthroughs are the same, but without cutscences oh and you play as stupidly op characters that make you roll over everything with barely any challenge. I believe this to be a good game, but if you can't handle that there's next to no story then I'd recommend not playing it. If you're a DMC fan or a fan of hack and slash games then this is for you, or rather hitting things and feeling good about yourself. Good game I would say it ranks above DMC2 and below DMC1 above that being DMC3.

106566323.review:
This game is great and bad at the same time.

The story is forgettable. I don't really like Nero as a character. He's got no motivations other than a girl whom he loves, which isn't necessarily bad, but then again, the female interest is basically an anime cardboard cutout. Dante is Dante. Overall the narrative won't hold your interest and is really weak.

The graphics are good. Not spectacular, but good. Environments are ok, with some of the architecture that looks impressive. I like the character models, which feel a bit anime-esque. Enemy design could have been better.

The gameplay is the core reason why you should play the game. The combat system is great, though I wish there was more variety to the Devil Bringer Arm. You can chain combos, on ground, mid-air, parry even the ultimate moves of bosses, it's great. Nero has just one sword and gun, Dante has three. Some of the enemies feel not suitable for Dante. (Cutlass, Mephisto) Would have been nice if both characters were balanced. The puzzles and platforming sections feel disjointed, instead of what ideally should be an occasionally  breather from the breakneck combat.

Bosses are tough and visually imposing. Not DMC3 tough, but tough nevertheless. On harder difficulty, they unleash some additional moves, which is nice. Nero doesn't gain any weapons after defeating them, but Dante does sometimes. Also, why does Dante have to basically backtrack what Nero did? He doesn't have any unique bosses to fight, with the exception of Saviour, and that battle isn't that great. It kind of proves the-bigger-they-are-the-harder-they-fall theory, which shouldn't be the case. But I'm satisfied with the boss battles in DMC 4, and really enjoyed battling some of them.

This could have been an excellent game, but it's still good. If they focused a bit on the story and characters and avoided annoying puzzles and backtracking, this could've been a classic. 
I still like it quite a bit.

8.5/10

105444888.review:
A game I can only dream of mastering.

DMC4 suffers from a rushed development which is both its fatal flaw and saving grace. Series newcomer Nero has a half-campaign with well designed but faced paced levels. Upon hitting mission 12, the player changes to Dante, who has an insane movelist and freedom of player expression. The issue is that Dante retraces Nero’s steps for his levels and sees 1 unique room and that’s it. It really hampers the game. 
However, DMC4 has objectively the most complex mechanics of any DMC game due to the jank caused by it’s rushed development. If you learn to exploit this, you can do fucking insane anime-fight movement and do dramatic and artistic combos. For most people though, it’ll just be like the gameplay in 5.

Stage design is great and the game’s presentation still holds up well. It’s not pretty by any means but it doesn’t look like most games from the late 2000s.

Enemy design is unfortunately pretty bad. The basic scarecrow enemies are fine, but almost everything else isn’t fun to fight, ranging from annoying to flat-out unfun. Mephistos and Fausts need to be shot a bunch to drop their shield to do real damage. Galdius’ (Gladii?) and Cutlasses keep out of your reach and aren’t that interesting. Frosts are very tanky and have powerful and frustrating freeze attacks. Alto Angelos boost the abilities of Bianco Angelos (which isn’t a huge deal but typically they come in packs with 1 alto and 5 or 6 bianco angelos). Chimeras are unbelievably mean. Fuck the chimeras. I want to personally shit on and murder whoever designed this shit. Blitzes are frustrating and poorly designed but are pretty easy when you know how to drop their electric armor. Most enemies in the game are listed here.

DMC4:SE adds a bunch of content. Vergil is playable, and is busted. Lady is really interesting. Trish is busted and super easy. Fun though. The new Legendary Dark Knight mode is a slightly less punishing Son of Sparta difficulty with a ton of enemies. Hell and Hell mode pushes the definition of masochism, especially with the enemies in this game. 

All in all DMC4 is a niche title. If you’re new to the series, play 5! It’s a great introduction. If you like 5 a lot and want to see how the series has grown, pick up 4:SE. It has the most complex and dynamic combat I’ve ever seen and is a pretty ok game for those not interested in the high level stuff. 6.5/10 but my favorite game of all time.

Improves on the mechanics of the previous games, and Nero feels really good to play. I think I liked 1 and 3 better overall still, but this one's still fun. I just liked the personalities of the other games a bit better, but this one still has everything that you'd expect.

You play through most of this game as Nero, who has a cool arm! He's really fun to fight bosses as, because when they're in a staggered state you can grab them and mess them up with your demon arm! Later on you'll swap to playing as Dante and basically backtrack through every level you played as Nero, but it's still fun. Dante has different interactions with bosses, plays much differently, and the levels are condensed and spiced up a bit for your return trip. I've seen complaints about how you're basically playing the same game twice, but I'd say that the levels you play as either character were definitely different enough for me.

I wasn't a big fan of the final boss and final few levels of this game though. No spoilers ofc, but it had one of the most boring boss fights I've ever played, and one of the last levels was just a filler episode where u moved along, maybe fought waves of enemies, and just had repeat bosses appear to fight for no reason before the end.

105057359.review:
Although not as polished as some of its brethren, Devil May Cry 4 is still a decent game. Despite a lot of assets (mostly boss fights) being reused in the story, Devil May Cry 4's Special Edition allows you to play with 5 different playstyles: Nero, Dante, Vergil, Lady and Trish. All of the characters have their own unique movesets and style of play, and it helps to distract from some of the game's flaws. The story, in my opinion, is actually decent as well. Unlike previous titles, the game actual starts by following newcomer to the series (at the time), Nero, who bears a strange devil arm (literally). While Dante is present, he doesn't come in and kill everything in one blow, like he probably would if you were playing as him. Instead he plays more of a mentor role for Nero, only really stepping in when things get serious. Generally, I'd say this is a good game, and people who want to get into Devil May Cry should definitely start here or with Devil May Cry 3.
